4583311/4578599/4591664.text: In this locality the boys make a great many toys Such as Cribs which are used for catching birds  How a crib is made is you make a square out of four pieces of sticks. Then you bring a doubled piece of scick up from each corner of the square and weve sticks across every side and when it is buit to the top where the sticks all meet together the building part is finished. 4583352/4582242/4591945.title: Homemade Toys
4583352/4582242/4591945.text: Long ago toys were not manufactured as largely as they are now, and it was only the children of the very rich that could get mechanical toys. The children of the poor depended on their parents and relatives skill for their toys. In those days rag dolls were made, and also little cars out of a big shoe box and four spools. Toys were also cut out of paper, such as dancing dolls, hats and cages. Boys used to play with two toys called catapults, slings, tops and balls. The catapult was made out of small pieces of leather and long strings. Children are always fond of playing with toys and even if their parents cannot afford to get them toys they invent toys for themselves and they often used sticks as horses.

4583352/4582243/4591949.title: Homemade Toys
4583352/4582243/4591949.text: Long ago the people used to make a lot of toys for their children. They used to make little motor-cars out of turnips and put timber wheels on them. They used to make cattarpults for the boys for killing birds. They were made with the fork of a tree and a bit of rubber. They used to make tops with spools and put nails on the ends of them. They used to make fifes out of pumps and they used to put a cork on the end of them.They made little horses out of turnips and they put timber legs on them.

4583352/4582244/4591952.title: Homemade Toys
4583352/4582244/4591952.text: Long ago the people used to make a lot of home made toys for their children. They used to make tops out of spools, by cutting it in the shape of a top, and by putting a nail in it. They used to make dolls out of sticks, by putting a turnip for a head and two coals of fire for two eyes. They also used to make prams out of boxes, by putting two spools for two wheels, and by putting two handles on it.

4583354/4582277/4592210.title: Homemade Toys
4583354/4582277/4592210.text:
When children get holidays from school they usually spend their time making toys.Boys are very fond of making small stools, bows - and - arrows, stone-slings, snares, bird-cages and many others. On a windy day they make paper kites and fly them in the air.Bow and arrows, are made with sticks which can bend. A stick of an ash tree is the best. The stick is slightly arched and the two ends are tied together with twine or a strip of rubber, and an arrow made from a stick shot from it.A sling is made from a long twine, and a piece of leather with two or three small holes in it. The leather is fastened in the middle, some stones are put into the holes, and the sling is whirled round quickly and the stones fly off.Girls like making rag-dolls. They stick pieces of cloth into the shape of hands, feet, body, and hand. They then stuf them with saw-dust, they either paint or stick eyes, noses, and mouths on them.Some children can make dancing dolls out of wood and wire. Girls also make dolls houses, some
(continues on next page)

4583321/4579660/4592467.title: Homemade Toys
4583321/4579660/4592467.text:
Home-made toys.Cribs were made long ago for catching birds in the snow thus:- Two stout pieces of sticks about a foot long, were got and two holes were put near by at the end of them.  Into these holes were stuck the ends of two other sticks, thinner but of the same length.  Thus forming a square.  Two equal pieces of twine were hung loosly diagonally from corner to corner.  Now the building commenced.  Two thin sticks were got and laid over the two ends under the twine, to more were laid on the sides over the first two and two more over the two and so on until a little house was shaped like a bee-hive with a flat top.    In the process of making the strings got more taut with every stick put in until at last they were as firm as sticks themselves.  Under-neath was a hoop made of a rod attached to the ends of one of the first sticks.  The crib was partly raised and a short stick like a hay fork was put up against it.  There was another rod going from the fork if the upright to the hoop. When the bird hopped on the hoop, the rod gave way and down fell the crib and the bird was cap-
(continues on next page)

A stick was pared to the thickness of the hole with a knob left on top.  This was for shoving in and firing pellets.  The pellets were made of raw potatoes or turnips.  Contests were held between the boys in the district.Margaret Keaveny  Spring-GardenInfo got from Mrs Keaveny  Spring-Garden.Age 50 years.

Home-made Toys.The girls made chains of daisies, peg-wood and dog briar.  They got a strong needle and thread and they put the needle through the middle of each berry. 4583320/4579464/4593228.text:
1. Nobody ever made toys around here to the memory of the oldest inhabitant except Johnny Mullin of Ballygowan. He used to make dancing dolls out of wood and they used perform to the time of music in the hands of a musician or a handy man. 2. Several of the older farmers used to make baskets for household purposes such as taking turf into the house or picking potatoes. The Downey's of Ballygowan used make cribs to catch birds. 3. There were people in Carrocrin named Heagney's.They used make cleaves for picking potatoes and straining them.4. A man named Tim Kelly used make axles,
(continues on next page)

4583320/4579524/4593393.title: Homemade Toys
4583320/4579524/4593393.text:
1. The old people were great for making toys. The people nowadays are not able to make those toys at all. Ned Larkin made a cleave in a barn for bringing in turf etc. When he had it finished it was to big, it would not go out the door, he had to break it up again.2. A man by the name of Johny Mullin used to make dancing masters to amuse children. They used to be made with timber and bound with wire.3. A girl by the name of Elena Ford used to make weather guides out of timber. She made a man and the woman when a man comes out it is the sign of wet-weather.
(continues on next page)

4602675/4594468/4616494.title: Homemade Toys
4602675/4594468/4616494.text:
In olden times the little girls were very interested (such as) in making toy dolls and necklaces of daisies. To-day the little girls are still able to make necklaces out of daisies. The boys are able to make spinning tops from thread spools, and are also able to make cradle-cribs for catching small birds. They also make snares for catching rabbits and hares.The rag dolls were made in the following manner, the girls get pieces of cloth and cut them different shapes for the head, the body, the legs and arms. Then they stuffed the body and head with salt or bran, and stitched the different parts together. The girls then got coloured pencils and painted the eyes, mouth, and nose of the doll. The making of daisy necklaces is still carried on in my locality.
(continues on next page)

When the fine Summer days come all the young boys and girls make neck laces out of Daisies, and make chains out of Dandy Lines. The boys also make cribs for catching birds and this is how they make them. First they make a frame and join them together at each end. Then they build it up until they reach the top and then they tie it with a piece of string. They also make spinning taks out of thread spools. They often get a turnip and make the shape of a mans head and scoop out the eyes, mouth, ears, and nose, and make a hole in the back of it for a candle and that frightens all the people going the road. They also make cages for birds and often make trap-cages to set on top of the cage. They boys also make cribs for catching the birds and this is how they do it. First they make a frame and join them together at each end and then they tie it. Then they
(continues on next page)

4613678/4607737/4616984.title: Toys and Pastimes
4613678/4607737/4616984.text:
The young girls make necklaces out of flowers in the Summer. Boys still make cribs for catching birds and they also make catapults. The boys do not play marbles or tops nowadays.



The young girls used makes hats out of rushes. My parents never heard of people making dolls or cutting patterns out of paper.The boys make pop-guns out of a piece of elder stick and a piece of a spring of a clock.Boys still make slings out of a bit of leather and two bits of sting.They also make catapults from a piece of an elder stick and a tube of a bicycle.

4613678/4607737/4616985.title: Toys and Pastimes
4613678/4607737/4616985.text:
The young girls make necklaces out of flowers in the Summer. Boys still make cribs for catching birds and they also make catapults. The boys do not play marbles or tops nowadays.



The young girls used makes hats out of rushes. My parents never heard of people making dolls or cutting patterns out of paper.The boys make pop-guns out of a piece of elder stick and a piece of a spring of a clock.Boys still make slings out of a bit of leather and two bits of sting.They also make catapults from a piece of an elder stick and a tube of a bicycle.

4613678/4607738/4616986.title: Toys and Pastimes
4613678/4607738/4616986.text: All boys make pop - guns out of elder sticks by getting a red hot iron and burning out the white stuff and putting in a spring of an alarm clock, the boys use burned matches them for firing at each other.Long ago girls used make hats out of rushes. Young boys make cribs out of boards to catch gold finches and green linnets for singing.

4591092/4589888/4623810.title: Local Cures
4591092/4589888/4623810.text:
(continued from previous page)
you should go three successive times to his house not before sunrise or after sunset. In former times when people were affected with mumps or the leacnac as it was called, they used to tie a stocking of hot potatoes around their neck and after some time it would disappear.



[-]
(continues on next page)

4591092/4589891/4623815.title: Homemade Toys
4591092/4589891/4623815.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



In former times young boys and girls found amusement in making toys and other things during my spare time.      For example children made dolls , marbles , jack-stones , from 'dabe' which was fine sand they discovered at a brink of a river ,and
(continues on next page)

4613672/4607072/4624008.title: Enchanted Lakes
4613672/4607072/4624008.text:
(continued from previous page)
was the custom then) when all of a sudden a big black shapless monster came out o'the lake.  The women became afraid an' ran for their lives.  The animal lay on the shore for a short time an' then went back to the lake again.



Home-made ToysThe girls around here do not make so many toys, but the boys do as they play more games than the girls such as catching birds which they require a crib for etc.In summer when the flowers are in bloom girls make chains or wreaths from flowers especially daisies by threading one stem into another.  They also make rag-dolls by getting a piece of cloth and sewing it up in an oblong shape and stuffing it with some rag or saw-dust.  Then another piece is cut in a round shape and stuffed like the first.  This round piece is then sewed on to the oblong one.  One forms the head and the other the body.  Little pieces of wood are then attached to the body for
(continues on next page)

4613674/4607317/4624384.title: Homemade Toys
4613674/4607317/4624384.text:
In this parish long ago several toys were made by the people to amuse themselves. They made toys out of spools and pointed them and they were able to make them spin. They made toys out of oak and they used to whip them with a string. They had water-guns and they were able to fire water out of them about ten yards. They were able to suck up water and hold it for a day. They were made out of fuarans with cotton and a stick. They had a pop-gun made out of a piece of a rod and it burned in the centre. In it there was a string and it was able to fire a nail or a stone about twenty yards. They were able to fire very correct with them. They were able to make make little wooden out of three bits of timber. Two of them his
(continues on next page)

4602725/4598557/4627169.title: (no title)
4602725/4598557/4627169.text:
own. They got a rush and peeled the out side off it and left one strip of green on it and tied a bundle of them and put them up in a dry place. Then they melted tallow and dipped the rush in it. Then they got a turnip and a stick and put the stick into the heart of the turnip and put a split in the side of the stick. Then they put the rush into the stick. They called them tallow candles.



(continued from previous page)
About one hundred years ago there were no toys to be got in shops so the people had to make toys of their own. The boys used to make bows and arrows from the ribs of an umbrella. And they used to make kites from a little piece of light timber and paper. Then they flew it with a long cord. They used to make marbles from blue clay. And they used to make spinning tops from thread spools. When the thread would be all wasted off the spool the boys used to get them.

4602725/4598556/4627173.title: (no title)
4602725/4598556/4627173.text:
(continued from previous page)
fine flax and stuck it on the head. They bored the eyes and mouth with a hot iron. Long ago when the people had no lamps they made rush candles. They peeled the green of the rush all to a little narrow strip to keep the inside together. Then they melted tallow the fat of a pig and left it in a cool place to harden. A long time ago when people were very much afraid of ghosts sometimes the people would get a large turnip cut the inside out of it and cut the face of a man in it and put a candle inside it. Then when night would come they would light it and put it in some fence or bushes to scare people. About six years ago someone in upper Wardhouse put one in the bushes to scare people coming home from rambling.



Long ago the people made their own toys. They used to get a piece of cloth and stuff it with rags. They got a nail then and put it in the fire and burned out two eyes a nose and mouth. They also made rush candles of their
(continues on next page)

4622992/4621768/4629699.title: Homemade Toys
4622992/4621768/4629699.text:
Many toys are still made in this district. Daisy chains, whistles, and dolls are made by the girls and tops, snares and Cribs are made by the boys.A top was made from a piece of timber pointed at one end.The timber generally used was got from a crab tree. This is very hard timber and it is nearly impossible to split it.Grooves are cut all round the sides so as to keep the twine in position. Then a piece of pointed steel is got at the forge and attached on at the narrow end.A ring is made in the ground and everyone pegs his top and trys to get it spinning inside the circle. If one fails to spin one's top inside the circle his top is stuck in the centre of the ring and everyone gets a shot at it. Tops are often split in this way so needless to say no one likes to have his top put up for a cockshot.
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: M. Ó Dubhláin, M. Ó Muineacháin

4622996/4622054/4630247.title: Toys
4622996/4622054/4630247.text: The children have a number of toys. They make tops out of spools. They gather little sticks and make cribs for catching birds and they make snares of wire for catching wild animals. They gather the little daisies and make daisy chains and wear them around their necks.

4622997/4622178/4630478.title: Homemade Toys
4622997/4622178/4630478.text: Girls string chains from daisies and they make dolls from cloth and saw-dust. Boys make tops, pop-guns, cribs snares and heads out of turnips. Tops are made from thread spoon with a little stick stuck down through the hole. Pop-guns are made from elder branches with the inside take out. A bit of rubber at the end and then tye it with twine. Put in a sharp pointed stick and pull back half the stick with rubber and let go. Cribs are used for catching birds during the winter. They are made of elder branches and sally-rods entwined. The children make heads out of turnips. Snare-wire is very light wire and there must be four threads of it in a snare before it would catch a rabbit. Then there must be a loop in the snare to let the wire run quickly when the rabbit is caught. There must be a stick put under the snare to keep it up. There must be a strong stick put at one end of it and when the snare is set it must be stuck firmly in the ground so not to let the snare go with the rabbit.

4602722/4598403/4631443.title: Homemade Toys
4602722/4598403/4631443.text:
The boys and girls around this district amuse themselves in making different kinds of toys. Girls make dolls with rags and different kinds of cloth.They sew a piece of white cloth for the head, then they make the face with ink. The body is made, and joined to the head.The (body) boys make a lot more toys than girls. They make tops, bird cradles, guns, paper boats and models out of turnips. When they are making tops, they cut a spool until it is like a pointed pencil. the way they make a gun is, they cut a small  branch about a foot long off an elder tree. Then they clean out all the pith, and then cut a small hole in it, then a bit of tin is put into the hole, so that when it is pulled, it
(continues on next page)

4602730/4599252/4631733.title: Homemade Toys
4602730/4599252/4631733.text:
A lot of home made toys were made long ago by children amusement. girl made strings of daisies and primrose to put round their necks. Boys made spinning toys from spools they got a spool and in the centre and got small piece of stick and put it in the hole. They made bird cradles from sally[?] rods and put them outside and caught birds. girl made dolls from card board and a piece
(continues on next page)

4602736/4599716/4632889.title: Local Cures
4602736/4599716/4632889.text:
(continued from previous page)
Prayers were said in all these cures. I witnessed them all myself



I used to make spinny jinneys by cutting a spool and putting a piece of stick in the hole tapered to a fine point. This would revolve a long time when started off with a spin. The finer the point on the smoother the surface the longer it would spin. Whoever could make it spin the longest was the winner.



Work begun on Friday will be completed very early or very late. Work begun on Saturday will always be finished early. Anything sown on Good Friday will grow.Sunday is a good day to move to a new home. "Sundays flittin many a long day sittin".

4602743/4600279/4633854.title: Local Toys
4602743/4600279/4633854.text: The spinny jimmy is still a favourite toy among children. Ir is made out of a spool. The spool is cut away into a point at one end and a stick is put in the hole and then it is thrown on the floor and it spins for about ten minutes. The old people say that if it is made right you could give it three kicks without tossing it. Another game is making daisy chains girls especially make daisy chains. A hole is put in the stem of each daisy and then one is put in to the other this game is now dying out.

4602749/4600875/4634123.title: Homemade Toys
4602749/4600875/4634123.text: A piece of Sallyrod or any other sappy wood about 3 inches long and not very thick was procured. A cut was put through the skin all round about midway. A slanting piece was cut-off one end and a nick taken out about half an inch below this. Then it was tapped with a knife to loosen the skin which was slipped off from the midway cut. The pointed end had a flat piece removed from the nick to the end and the skin put on again.            This made a fine whistle.                                piece of wood with a                                               peel on it.                                 cut at dotted lines and                                 tap gently.                                peel removed from                                                        half and small strip                                removed from nick                                to point                                complete whistle.                               with peel put back                                again where it was                               originally.A chestnut had a round hole put in the top of the shell and the pulp picked out to make a whistle.(Sixty years ago the pupils attending Farnaughs N.S S Leitrim made these whistles.)

4602752/4601173/4634320.title: Homemade Toys
4602752/4601173/4634320.text:
There was not as many toys long-go as there is at present.Toys were made from thread spools and other pieces of timber. The way they made it from spools was - They  would cut the spool in two halves, and then get a piece of a stick. Then they would tear it down until it would be a fit for the hole in the spool. They would stick it in then, and if it was not big enough they would put a bit of rag around it. When they had that finished they would spin it on the floor or on any other thing, that it would spin on. Guns were made from a piece of buar [?] tree or a piece of alder. They would put a hole in the middle of the buar [?] tree or in the alder, but the common one was the buar [?] tree, because it is soft in the heart and it would be easy to put a hole in it. When they would have that done they would get a fistful of suds, they would blow through the hole in the buar [?] tree, and the suds would go off in bubbles.Snares were made from sire around here. There was not a farm around here long go but there was a snare
(continues on next page)

4602749/4600926/4634375.title: Toy-Making
4602749/4600926/4634375.text: The girls made dolls out of old clothes. They got paper and made several pleats in it and when opened out & tied at one and this made a fan.To make a necklace they gathered a bunch of daisies took the stems off, and strung the blossoms on to a length of twine, with a needle. They also made little chains with Dandelion stems.Gordon Wilson   Long ago boys used to make baskets from chestnuts They used to cut a bib off both sides of the chestnut top, leaving a handle in the middle, and then scoop out the pulp. They used to sex snares near a rabbit burrow and then they would go out next morning to get the rabbits To make the snare they got a long piece of wire, about twice the thickness of a piece of thread and double[?] for 4 times and [?], and left a wee loop on one end, for the other end to go through.If your leg goes asleep spit on your hough.

4602749/4600927/4634383.title: Crafts - Utensils
4602749/4600927/4634383.text:
From Grandmother Mrs. Sharpe Danabeg 80 yrs.Wooden spoons used to be made out of little bits of timber. They were called "Knanskins" wooden vessels for holding milk called "Piggins" were also used and wooden mugs called "noggins" they also used wooden eggcups.



Home made Polish  Ethel MooreLong ago when people had no such stuff as polish, they made what they called polish out of soot and water, and rubbed this on their shoes on Sundays.Whips  Old men years ago used to make their whips out of rushes. For the handle they got a fairly thick bundle of long rushes, and rolled others round and round this to make a handle. The ends were plaited to make a leash.Home made toys  Ethel Moore from mother.Long ago when toys were not very plentiful boys & girls used to make their own. The boys got chestnuts and scooped the inside part out through a hole in the top and this made a whistle.They made little pipes out of acorns off oak trees. They also made pipes by scooping the seeds out of of hips to make the bowl and they made the shank with a piece of stick.



Whips  Old men years ago used to make their whips out of rushes. For the handle they got a fairly thick bundle of long rushes, and rolled others round and round this to make a handle. The ends were plaited to make a leash.



Home made toys  Ethel Moore from mother.Long ago when toys were not very plentiful boys & girls used to make their own. The boys got chestnuts and scooped the inside part out through a hole in the top and this made a whistle.They made little pipes out of acorns off oak trees. They also made pipes by scooping the seeds out of of hips to make the bowl and they made the shank with a piece of stick.

4602764/4602446/4634387.title: Homemade Toys
4602764/4602446/4634387.text:
In this district there are a great many home made toys made by the people especially by the children. Here is a toy which the children always like to have to play with. First of all they get two polish boxes and bore a hole through each box with a nail. When the hole is bored they get a stick suitable for the hole and put it from one side to another, and then it is put hurling on the floor, you can have lots of fun with this. This toy is called a Yo-Yo.Another toy which is played is a top.First when the thread is used off a spool, each end of the spool is pared and a piece of stick put in the ends
(continues on next page)

4602764/4602452/4634391.title: Homemade Toys
4602764/4602452/4634391.text:
A long time ago the people used to catch birds in a bird craddle.  To make a bird craddle, first get four sticks and put them down in the ground and run them through the other sticks, and tie them wit bits of strings. Then put a bit of a strick across the cradle.  When the bird hops on this stick the cradle falls down and the bird is caught.To make a catapult get two rubbers and a forked stick.  Then put the rubbers on the stick.  Then cut a piece of leather and put it on to the two rubbers.  Then put a stone into the rubber and catch hold of the stick
(continues on next page)

4602750/4601023/4634822.title: Homemade Toys
4602750/4601023/4634822.text: In olden times there were no toys to be bought in a shop- they were all home-made toys. All sorts of toys were made such as bird crade, scout gun, yo-yo, catapult, bow and arrow, snare and a wind-mill.During the winter the boys spend their spare time making toys. When making a catapult, first a piece of stick is got and the shape of a V in it and a bit of rubber and with this they throw stones. A yo-yo is made by cutting a spool in two halves and put each half. A piece of cord is tied to the spool and hopped up and down. A bird cradle is made by getting four pieces of sticks. These are tied to a thread in the shape of a square. Five rods are got, a strong stick, a spool and a bit of tin is tied to the stick. A sucker is made by cutting a round piece of leather with a string fastened in the centre.This is pressed on a flag and when pulling it up it makes a great noise.A chain of flowers is made by putting daisies on a string one after another. In making a wind-mill I get a strong stick, piece of tin, nail, and a spool. Then I nail the tin and spool to the stick. This is made to scare crows from potatoes and corn. A bow and arrow is made by getting a stick and rubber and the rubber is tied to the stick and is made in the shape of a hoop. A piece of stick is put in the middle of the hoop and make [?] for the bird. The rubber is pulled and the stick will kill the bird.

4602759/4601856/4634886.title: Food in Olden Times
4602759/4601856/4634886.text:
(continued from previous page)
Easter[.]  Wodden noggins were used before cups were introduced.  Tea was first used in the year 1846.  This was the year of the famine.



Home made toys are very seldom made except on a wet day when there is nothing to be done.  Boys get little pieces of wood nails and a hammer and make a little cart.  Then they get dab to make a few horses.  The dab is very soft for a few days but at the end of three days it is as hard as a stone.  It is easy to break it.  They also can make strange little [?].  They clean out the inside of a turnip leaving about [?] of an inch outside.  They take a little paint and mark out the eyes mouth and nose with paint on the turnip.  The light [is] a short piece of a candle and put it inside.. When it gets dark they leave it some place to scare other children or even grown up people.  Girls make
(continues on next page)

4602761/4602121/4634915.title: Homemade Toys
4602761/4602121/4634915.text:
A Daisy ChainPull daisies, make a little hole in the stem of one and pull a daisy through, then make a hole in the stem of that one, and pull another daisy through.  Continued in this way until the chain is long enough for a necklace, or a girdle, or a bangle.  Fasten off by pulling the stem of the last daisy into the head of the first daisy.SkittlesCut 2 pieces of wood about 3" long and the same thickness.  Draw a ring on the road or field.  Set up 5 pieces of wood as shown [drawing of ring with 5 dots] cut 4 longer pieces about 9" in length and with these try to knock out the little ones outside the ring.  The centre counts 10 and each of the others 5 you can choose 25, 50, or 100 for the game.  If you "scale" the ring at one turn that is knock out the five outside the ring you have the game.
(continues on next page)

4602761/4602122/4634920.title: Homemade Toys
4602761/4602122/4634920.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Scout Guns. Get Scout, they are very plentiful in the fields. Cut at one of the joints. Pierce the end with knitting needle. Get a stick and roll a rag round it to make fit the other end of scout. Stick into water, and pull up stick and the scout will be full of water, Lift up, and plunge down stick, and  water will fly out. The stick is the ram-rod. MarblesMarbles were made out of clay. Red clay is best. A little piece of clay is rolled between the hands, and mixed with water if the clay is hard. When it is perfectly round, it is baked in the fire to harden, or sometimes rolled in hay and put in a dry place. WhistlesWhistles are made out of chestnuts. A small hole is made in chestnut, and all picked out of
(continues on next page)

4602759/4601871/4634929.title: Homemade Toys
4602759/4601871/4634929.text: Every boy and many girls find amusement in spare time in making toys.  Boys make dancers from thread spools and spinning it on the floor.  Children also make guns from elder branches by taking the heart out of them.  They then wet a bit of paper and put it into the gun and blow air into it, then they put another lump of paper in the other side and push it out.  This causes the last lump of paper to fly off with a big shot.In winter boys make bird cradles and set them under a hedge with a bit of bread inside.  They set snares in the mouth of the holes where the rabbit lives. Other boys make a man's head out of a turnip.  They light a candle and cut out two eyes and a mouth and set the candle inside it.  It is then called a false head.  A bird cradle is made with a lot of rods.  First of all there is a square made out of rods and then there are rods running every way through it.  It is set out in the field and a piece of bread in it.  And when the bird is coming into it she steps on the rod that holds up the cradle it then falls on her.

4602759/4601872/4634930.title: Homemade Toys
4602759/4601872/4634930.text: Food in Olden Times.In olden times people only ate three meals a day, breakfast, dinner and tea.  The breakfast was eaten about ten o'clock.  Two o'clock was dinner time.  Six o'clock was tea time.  People worked for two hours before having food in the morning.  In the morning they boiled potatos for their breakfast  and had mashed potatos for their dinner.  Oatmeal bread and milk was the usual food at their tea.Potatos were eaten twice a day.  Butter milk was the usual drink in olden  times.  People did not go to the table long ago.  They sat round the potato basket which was place on the middle of the floor.  The kitchen table was always hung up against the wall when not in use.  Oatmeal bread was eaten in olden times.  The oatmeal was put into a basin and wet with water and mixed.  It was then put on a bread iron in front of the fire.  They never ate meat during the seven weeks of Lent.  Meat was eaten only on Sunday the rest of the year.    It was salt meat they ate.  They used to eat fish very often.  All the vegatables that they used to eat are in fashion yet.  They ate nothing from six o'clock in the evening until the following morning.

4605934/4603729/4643143.title: Homemade Toys
4605934/4603729/4643143.text: Girls make daisy chains out of flowers and makes dolls dresses for their dolls.Boys make tops out of thread-spools, they make guns out of elder branches, birds cradles with which to catch birds, they make snares to catch rabbits, hares, and foxes, they make watches out of turnips, and stick candles in turnips and make whistles out of twigs of ash bushes, and out of chestnuts.  These amusements are carried on still. The cradle birds are made from sally rods and made into the shape of a basket and it is lifted up from the ground and a stick put under it, and when the bird goes in, he steps on the stick, and it falls down, and he is caught under it. The ways they make watches out of turnips is they cut a big turnip in two halves, and model a clock on it, and put two sticks for hands on it.   The way they make whistles out of chestnuts is, they cut out a hole in the chestnut, and then blow in to it, and it will whistle.The way snares are made is a piece of wire is got, a loop is put on it, and the other end is put into the loop, and a loop put on that end too.

4605930/4603450/4643442.title: Homemade Toys
4605930/4603450/4643442.text:
Toys now made by children in my district are fie-fays, marbles, men, houses and other things from daub, squirters, spinney-jinneys, pipes, catapults, rush whips and carts.  These were also made long ago.Fie-fays: Fie fays are made from pieces of straw.  The straw is clipped to about four inches long with a knot on one end of it.  A tongue is cut below the know.  The straw is placed in the mouth until the tongue is covered and then blown into.  It makes a noise like a toy bugle.Marbles men, houses These are made from daub the same way as they are made from plasticine.
(continues on next page)

4613716/4611878/4643740.title: Homemade Toys
4613716/4611878/4643740.text:
Tops were made from thread-spools or the knob of a drawer. A piece of stick was pushed through the hole of the spool and it was pointed. Sometimes the spool is pared.Cribs were made from elder branches or twigs. They were used for catching birds. They were shaped like a triangular pyramid. A "Gabhlóg", a "Chipín" and a "Bow" were used to set it. The "Bow" was a twig shaped like a semi-circle and stuck in at two corners at the bottom of the crib. The "Gabhlóg" was a fork shaped like the letter Y and was put standing against the crib. The "Cipín" was a short piece of a twig and it was bent. It was stuck in between the prongs of the "Gabhlóg" and put inside the "Bow". A couple of twigs were put across the "Bow" so that if a bird jumped up on one of them the "bow" falls down and he is caught inside in the crib.
(continues on next page)

4613716/4611879/4643748.title: Homemade Toys
4613716/4611879/4643748.text:
(continued from previous page)
When a bird perched on the "Bow" the "Cipín" fell out of the "Gabhlóg" and the crib fell with the bird inside in it.



Haw-shooters are made from the stalks of nettles because the stalk of a nettle is hallow inside. The boy eats the skins of the haws and then he blows the stones through the haw-shooter.Snares are made from thin wire tied at one end to a piece of stick and the loop made at the other. It is placed outside a rabbit burrow and when the the rabbit comes out his head gets caught in the loop and
(continues on next page)

4613716/4611880/4643750.title: Homemade Toys
4613716/4611880/4643750.text:
(continued from previous page)
he tries to escape the tighter the loop becomes.



To make a "bostoon" get seven long rushes or so and wind another long rush around them and fasten it at the top and you have a nice stick called a "bostoon".To make a soaker get a piece of leather about the size of a penny and bore a hole in the centre of it. Through this hole put a long cord and make a knot at the end of it. Things can be lifted from the ground by wetting the soaker and by pressing it against the object you want to pick up.
(continues on next page)

4605924/4602960/4643801.title: A Story
4605924/4602960/4643801.text:
(continued from previous page)
as many scallops growing on his back as would thatch all the houses in the townland.



Every boy and girl likes to make home made toys and this is one I make myself in the Summer. I get a wisp and I pick some daisies which grow in in the meadow. I pluck off the stem up as far as the flower. I put a whole through the middle of the flower. I continue this until I fill the wisp. I put a knot on the wisp and I tie it round my neck or round my dress and I have what is called a daisy chain.This is another toy that boys and girls often make. They get an empty thread spool and they pair oneside of it off to a point. They get a bit of a stick and stick it down in the hole of the spool. Then it is made. They catch the bit of stick and whirl the pointed side around on a board. It spins away for some time. It causes amusement to watch it spin round.

4613719/4612402/4643819.title: Homemade Toys
4613719/4612402/4643819.text:
One day I made a doll out of cloth. This is the way made her. I got paper and made a ball of it and I put a cloth around it. That was her head. I made eyes and nose and mouth with black thread. Then I made her body with clothes and sewed it on to her head. I got two pieces of sticks and put a cloth around them and sewed it on to her body. These were her two hands. Then I got two more sticks and put another cloth around them and sewed them on to her body. These were her two legs. Then I made clothes for her and put them on her.Another day I made pram for her. I got a box and broke it up. Then I got five pieces of it and I got a hammer and nails and nailed the five of them together in the shape of a box. I put two wheels on to the bottom of it and I put two long handles on it. Then I went driving it. Then I went driving it around the house with the doll inside in it.
(continues on next page)

4613719/4612403/4643828.title: Homemade Toys
4613719/4612403/4643828.text:
(continued from previous page)
Another toy you could make out of daisies is a necklace. You should get a bunch of daisies and put a little hole through the stem of one and put the other one through it and you should keep at that all the time until you would have it long enough put it around your neck.



Toys of many kinds can be made by children. There is one known as a crib for catching birds. The frame is composed of four sticks of equal length fastened together by tacks in the form of a square. Cords are tied diagonally to the frame. Twigs are laid around this square one upon another. They are getting smaller as they reach the top until it is finished.

4602753/4601253/4643850.title: Homemade Toys
4602753/4601253/4643850.text: A lot of home made toys were made long ago. Boys made guns out of elderberry branches. They got a straight piece of a branch and cleaned the heart out of it and they blew haws and pieces of paper out of them. The boys also made bird cradles and snares. They made the bird cradles out of wood and the snares out of thin wire, and the spinning tops were made out of spools. The girls made dolls from wasc and card-board and pieces of coloured cloth.When parents were young they used to play with marbles, balls jack in the box and walk on stilts. There were no toys at all.

4605940/4604223/4644030.title: Homemade Toys
4605940/4604223/4644030.text: 1. Every boy and many girls find amusement in spare time in making toys.2. Girls love to make daisy chains, rag dolls' and dolls' dresses.3. Daisy chains are made by putting a split in the stem of the daisy and another daisy is pulled through it and so on until the chain is long enough.4. A rag doll is made by filling a cloth of rags and sewing it up in the shape of a body.5. The head, hands and feet are made of card-board.  The mouth, eyes, ears and nose are marked with paint.6.Then the clothes are made and put on and the it was finished.

4605940/4604224/4644036.title: Homemade Toys
4605940/4604224/4644036.text: Boys take great interest in making bird cradles tops and scouting guns.  The bird cradle is of a triangular shape made from boortree rods.  The tops are made from thread spools and strings are put round them in order to spin them.  The scouting gun is made like a bicycle pump from the elder branches.  In spare time there are some of the toys the boys like to make.  Sometimes these toys are brought to shows and whatever boy has the best made toys he will get some little prize and so the next show he may get a bigger prize.  The girls amuse themselves in making daisy chains, rag dolls and dolls dresses.

4613718/4612199/4644929.title: Homemade Toys
4613718/4612199/4644929.text: Long ago the little boys used to make themselves tops, guns and other toys.TopsTops were made from spools. First the end of the spool was pointed and the hole plugged. Then an iron spear or nail with the head cut off was driven up through the plug.

4613718/4612201/4644953.title: Homemade Toys - Homemade Lamps
4613718/4612201/4644953.text: First of all a crock is procured and a wee turnip. Then there is a hole made in the turnip and a small piece of candle put into the hole and put in the bottom of the crock. Then a piece of wire is tied to the top of the crock and a second piece is attached to this to form a handle. Then a cover of a polish is holed and put on. The candle is lighted and the cover put on and it is a pretty lamp.

4613718/4612202/4644956.title: Homemade Toys - Clappers
4613718/4612202/4644956.text: First a piece of paper was got and folded in several parts. Then it was cut down through the middle and folded in once more.To clap with it put it in between your two fingers and draw the fingers up along it and it would make a noise like 'clapping'.

4613718/4612203/4644958.title: Homemade Toys - A Catapult
4613718/4612203/4644958.text: First of all a gablog is got. This is made of sally rods. Then two pieces of rubber of equal length are procured. Then a piece of leather is got and holes made at each side of it and tied with a cord. These two rubbers are also attached to the gablog and it is then finished.

4613718/4612204/4644967.title: Homemade Whistles
4613718/4612204/4644967.text: First a piece of Elder was got and the heart scooped out. Then a hole was made in the side of the Elder. Next a haw was got and put into it and when the whistle was blown the haw flew around inside and made music.

4613718/4612205/4644970.title: Homemade Toys - How to Make a Sling
4613718/4612205/4644970.text: First a piece of leather and holed at each end and a cord put through the holes. Then a stone is put on the leather and the two ends of the cord are taken in the hand and swung; then one cord is let go and the stone goes too.

4613718/4612206/4644973.title: Homemade Toys - A Necklace
4613718/4612206/4644973.text: Long ago little girls used to make chains or necklaces from flowers. First the flowers were picked; then the stems were taken off and a thread drawn through the centre of each flower. They were fixed in different ways the backs and fronts arranged alternately. The principal flower used was the daisy and sometimes the petals were picked off and nothing left but the yellow disc.

4605945/4604665/4645076.title: Local Marriage Customs and Superstitions
4605945/4604665/4645076.text:
(continued from previous page)
straw-boys should be known. The ends of the straw (are) were platted so as to resemble horns. They wore belts of straw round their waists and sashes of coloured paper across their shoulders and they presented a very formidable appearance.After the straw-boys retired the dancing commenced again and continued until morning. Then all the guests left for home after wishing many happy years of married life to th Bride and Groom.



People long ago had many toys with which they amused themselves. Some of these toys will exist such as - Making daisy chains, Bird Cradles, Spinning tops and Bracelets.Girls often spend their leisure time gathering flowers and making daisy chains. A great number of daisies are gatheres and joined together by holing the stem of each daisy and then another daisy is stuck though the hole and so on until a lovely daisy chain is made. Then the girls wear them round their necks.

4649672/4645375/4650063.title: Playthings Made by the Boy of the Parish
4649672/4645375/4650063.text:
Scríobhnóir:  Micheál Ó GriallghaisCaisleán Gearr, GaillimhPlaythings made by the boy of the parishThe boys of this parish make many playthings, balls, rabbit-snares, hurleys, marbles, buzzers, pipes, tops, catapults, fifes, cradles, blasts and whistles.I saw Stephen King making a ball.  Four pint bottle corks are tied together by a piece of cloth.  Then woollen knitting thread is rolled around the corks and is made into the shape of a ball.  Then I sew a string through the thread to keep it together.  I use them for hurling.I have seen Bartley Murphy making rabbit snares.  They are made by making a noose in a piece of thin copper wire about eighteen inches long and tieing the end of the wire to a peg.  Then the peg is stuck
(continues on next page)

4583322/4579732/4650069.title: Homemade Toys
4583322/4579732/4650069.text: In olden times the children had no toys except those made locally. The girls used to make dolls out of rags. They used also make flowers out of coloured paper The boys used to have spinning tops. They used also play with marbles.They used to have snairs for catching rabbits and cribs for catching birds.They used to make lanterns from turnips.They used to make a motor-car with a small box and put spools under it for the wheels.

4649685/4646748/4650534.title: Homemade Toys
4649685/4646748/4650534.text:
From time immemorial, it was a customary thing, with all our Irish boys and girls, to occupy themselves by making toys on the rainy days, when it is too wet for the usual outdoor games.Numerous, indeed, were the articles manufactured by the children of all ages, and it is a shame to think that the children of to-day, would not dream of carrying on this profitable and pleasant work.Spinning-tops, guns, bird-cradles, snares, paper-kites, boats, carts, bows-and-arrows fishing-rods, slings, dolls, necklaces and girdles were made in
(continues on next page)
4649685/4646748/4650534.school_info: School: An Clochar, Cara Droma Ruisc

4649683/4646354/4650687.title: Homemade Toys
4649683/4646354/4650687.text: A bow an arrow made from a sally rod bent round slightly with a chord.  Then get a fairly long stick which makes the arrow.  This can be shot off by releasing the chord.A Sling is made from a piece of leather with a string on each end.  One piece of string is longer than the other and is wound round the hand.  The other piece is short.  A stone is placed in the leather + the string is swing round in a circle two or three times.  Release the short string, the stone flies off.Daisy chains were made in summer by putting the stem of one daisy through the stem of another, then keep on adding new ones.  Bilberries were gathered and put on straws.Hips were also strung + worn for beads.

4649700/4648400/4651135.title: Strange Animals
4649700/4648400/4651135.text:
(continued from previous page)
An té a thug an t-adhbhar  seo dom



Boys like spinning tops can very easily make one by getting an old spool on which there was thread and pare it out very fine on one end and paint it any colour. Bird cradles are very useful for catching birds. Get a lot of thin saly rods, and weave them in and out, and then when it is made, leave it out in the garden and put crumbs of bread in it. Then the birds will come on to take out the crumbs and they will get trapped in it. Little boys around this locality also make whistles out of chestnuts. They put a hole through it, and then they can whistle easily with it.

4649695/4648017/4651190.title: Homemade Toys
4649695/4648017/4651190.text:
(continued from previous page)
spinning.  Another thing that people spin is a penny and when it is spun very quick it looks like a thimble when it is in full force.  Here is how a bird cradle is made.  It is shaped like a box.  First the frame is made and then there is a stick made across it for the bird to perch on and when she perches on it she is trapped.

4649695/4648020/4651195.title: Homemade Toys
4649695/4648020/4651195.text:
(continued from previous page)
rods get shorter as they approach the top. Models from turnips are also made. Sometimes a small turnip is got fir the head and a big one fir the body. Then the big one is attached to the small one. Then nails are put in for arms and legs. Other times they get a big turnip was got and an animal’s or person’s shape is cut out in it. Various animals are also made from cardboard and corks and pieces of stick. The head of the animal is cut out in cardboard and his body is of cork. There is a slit put in the narrow end of the cork and the head is put into this slit. An animal has four legs therefore four holes are put in the bottom of the cork and four sticks are put into the holes. Birds are also made from cardboard and corks. Pipe cleaners are put for necks in some birds that have long necks. A feather is put for a tail and wings. Nails are put for feet.



Boys and girls find pleasure in making toys. I make toys from corks such as a pig, a fox, a rabbit, a rat and a duck and a giraffe. The body of the pig is made of
(continues on next page)

4649700/4648449/4651306.title: Homemade Toys
4649700/4648449/4651306.text:
Some children made their own toys, such as a spinning top for boys. They pair a spoll and drive a nail through it and have a top for spinning.The girls also make dolls dresses and furniture for a dolls house out of small pieces of wood. Some of the children buy their toys from the shops. You can make a doll dresser from a small box by putting sheleves into it. Long ago children in the spring used to make daisy chains with the daisies and other flowers. They used to make their own dolls by making a face on a piece of cardboard then they make the frock. Now-a-days the children get their toys from the shops.
(continues on next page)

4649700/4648457/4651346.title: Local Toy-Making
4649700/4648457/4651346.text:
Long ago the boys used to make their own toys. They made toys with spools. They pared one of the ends as fine as a needle and painted it any colour they liked. They made whistles with chestnuts. They took all the inside of the chestnut and when they blew into it they made music. The girls made braclets with daisies. They got a piece of twine and pull all the daisies on it and tied the two ends together. They made snares with wire. They got a  piece of wire and made a loop on the wire and when a small animal puts his into the loop it would tighten and the animal would get choked.
(continues on next page)

4649700/4648473/4651403.title: Toy-Making
4649700/4648473/4651403.text:
Long ago in Ireland little boys used to make tops for spinning, out of spools.  They made a yo-yo out of two spools and a peice of a stick in both spools and a cord by putting the stick in both spools and twisting the twine round the stick it was like a shop one.Girls could make dolls out of cardboard and cloth.  Also they could make figures of cats out of cardboards by getting a picture of one first and then they would cut her out on cardboard.Boys could make whistles out of chestnuts by boring them with a penknife and they could make a flute out of ferns.They uses bore six holes for the fingers and one for
(continues on next page)

4649700/4648503/4651483.title: Homemade Toys
4649700/4648503/4651483.text:
Home made ToysBracelets made from flowers are very common around around this district. At first the children gather a bunch of daisies or primroses. They make a make a hole in the stem of the daisy with a pin and put in a daisy in a hole. They do the same with the next daisy and so on until they have a long chain made. The make a hole in the last daisy and another one in the first and tie the two of them together with a thread. They can put it on them without opening it. The custom  of bracelets, are kept on still, but not as much as long ago. Instead of making necklaces they make bands for their hair which are made in the same way as the bracelets. Some children make half the bracelet with daisies, and the other half with primroses. Boys also amuse themselves by making boxes for clocks. They get a board from a tea-chest
(continues on next page)

4649706/4649050/4652003.title: Homemade Toys
4649706/4649050/4652003.text:
When I was a young I made a stool and a toy cart. When I was making the stool I got a board about an inch deep, and I made four holes at each end with an auger. I then got four sticks for legs and put each one of them into each hole. When I was putting the legs in I slanted them, because if I put them straight the stool would not stand I stra- tightened the legs with two inch nails. When I was making the cart I got three boards half an inch deep, and nailed them across two thick sticks for the body. These sticks were the shafts. I got two pram-wheels and an axle and fastened them to the body. I made two side boards by nailing tow narrow boards together, and two cross slats upon top of that. I had this cart for drawing manure, and hay. I had it for two or thee- three years.



Home-Made Toys.The only toys that I ever made at home were sleighs. I used them on frozen snow. First I got two pieces of round bars
(continues on next page)

4649706/4649050/4652006.title: Homemade Toys
4649706/4649050/4652006.text:
When I was a young I made a stool and a toy cart. When I was making the stool I got a board about an inch deep, and I made four holes at each end with an auger. I then got four sticks for legs and put each one of them into each hole. When I was putting the legs in I slanted them, because if I put them straight the stool would not stand I stra- tightened the legs with two inch nails. When I was making the cart I got three boards half an inch deep, and nailed them across two thick sticks for the body. These sticks were the shafts. I got two pram-wheels and an axle and fastened them to the body. I made two side boards by nailing tow narrow boards together, and two cross slats upon top of that. I had this cart for drawing manure, and hay. I had it for two or thee- three years.



Home-Made Toys.The only toys that I ever made at home were sleighs. I used them on frozen snow. First I got two pieces of round bars
(continues on next page)

4649696/4648125/4652234.title: Local Toys
4649696/4648125/4652234.text:
Birdcage. A cage for holding a bird in the house is made from wires with a timber bottomBird Cradle a trap for catching birds it is made from sally rods on a square base with four triangular sides meeting in a point at the topSpinning Jennies: A round piece of tin with mitres like a saw round the edge and a hole in the middle in which a piece of twine is put and is wound tight and will keep spinning for five minutesRabbit Snaring A piece of snare wire which is set in the field for snaring rabbits.Tops A toy for spinning round about is made from the tops of spoolsClay marbles Marbles for playing with and are made from yellow clay and the children play with them in SummerA flies cge Is made out of rushes there are about six rushes tied together at the top and they are sloped down in a triangular shape and the flies hop in and between the rushes and the rushes are
(continues on next page)

4613727/4613308/4652929.title: Homemade Toys
4613727/4613308/4652929.text: Most children amuse themselves especially country children by making little toys of their own such as boats, belts, rattlers, necklaces, chairs, dolls, and many other things. The boats are made from long leaves and paper and put sailing in the water. Sometimes belts are made from coloured sweet papers and when it is completed it is a very nice toy. Rattlers are made by gathering long rushes and weaving them like a basket. When it is nearly woven a small stone is put into it so as that it will rattle. Necklaces are made with daisies. This is done by means of getting a string and putting them into it. Dolls are made from a potato and a piece of stick and then it is dressed up with coloured dresses. Some girls weave rushes into the form of a chair for their dolls.

4649702/4648622/4652985.title: Folklore - Homemade Toys
4649702/4648622/4652985.text:
In olden times it was a favourite pastime for people to scoop a turnip with the exception of a thin layer, a lighted candle was put into the space and with the light reflecting on the turnip it looked from a distance like a  ball of fire.  This was often left in a ditch to frighten timorous people.  Snares are made from fine wire.  They are set for rabbits and hares on their passes.  The snares are set in a circular shape, wide enough to enable the rabbits to get their heads into it, and in an effort to escape they eventually get choked. Snares are supported with small uprights with a split in the upright and the wire fits into the split.  The upright is tied to a bush in such a way that
(continues on next page)

4613728/4613443/4658518.title: Homemade Toys
4613728/4613443/4658518.text:
Nearly every boy and girl in my school - district makes his own toys when they have time to spare.  The girls make dolls with scraps of coloured cloth and a bit of timber for the dolls head.Boys make tops from empty thread-spools by pointing a thin stick to put through the hole, and then verging the sides with an edged knife.  Then a long cord is wound round it and is let go.  In Spring usually tops are spun.In the Winter "cribs" are used by boys to trap birds.  The cribs are made from elders.  When well pared they are put one upon the other and tied firmly so as to prevent all means of escape.  This is a
(continues on next page)

4658434/4655220/4659650.title: Homemade Toys
4658434/4655220/4659650.text:
In this district children are very fond of making home made toys during their spare time. Here are some of the things which they make: tops, dancing men, guns, bird-cradles and snares also girls make chains from the flowers that grow in the fields. A top is made from a spool. The spool is cut very narrow on one end and it is left the same way on the other side and then a stick is put through the hole in the spool and cut very fine and then it is ready for use.  It is very few children who can make a dancing man although it is very easy. First a piece of wood is got and small bit is cut off and a body is made from it. Then a head is made from another piece of wood and a nose and eyes are burned out by a hot nail. After this two legs are cut out and fastened to the body by two pins one in each leg. A hold is put in his head and a cord is put through this hole. Two persons catch a hold of the cord one at each end, and one of the  persons (stricks) strikes the cord on one end and at this the man starts to dance.
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: T. Ó Móráin, A. Ó Corraidhin

4649703/4648759/4659835.title: Composition on Homemade Toys
4649703/4648759/4659835.text:
The young people of long ago made toys to amuse themselves in their space time.  Girls used to string flowers together into a chain and also made dolls from pieces of cloth.  Then they would get ink to mark out the eyes, nose and mouth.The boys made top from pieces of timber or thread spools.  They a nail in them and used to spin them by means of a cord.  The older boys used to make guns out of a piece of boretree.  They scooped a hole in it and put a pin in it to shoot with.  They were called bullet guns.The boys made bird cages for catching birds.  The cages were made out of rods.  They were left set in the snow.  They left red berries in them to tempt the birds to go in them.There were snares made for catching hares and rabbits also.  These snares were made out of wire and were left at the rabbits burrows.  The children used to make cages from rushes
(continues on next page)

4658428/4654417/4659983.title: How to Make a Bird Cradle
4658428/4654417/4659983.text: How to Make a bird CradleComposition written by James Browne ClooneeIn the winter time when snow and frost are on the ground birds can easily be caught in a bird cradle. I have often made a bird cradle to catch the birds.The first thing I did was to cut a good many light rods and a few strong ones. I cut the four strong rods and I left each of them about a foot long. I tied them together so that they made a square, and I tied the tops of these rods together also. Then I platted the other rods in through those until it was all closed.

4658428/4654418/4659993.title: How I Play Tig
4658428/4654418/4659993.text:
I would put all the girls that were playing with me in a line and count to a certain number and who ever the number fell on had to run after me until they caught me and then I would run after them until I caught some other one. We would keep at it until we got tired running.



One day I made a top from a spool I got an empty spool and I pared off one end with a sharp knife I kept pointing it until I had it like a pencil point. Then i made a whip and began to flog it.

4658462/4657982/4660669.title: Homemade Toys
4658462/4657982/4660669.text:
A "Secret Gun" The home made toy which takes the lead in our house is a toy which my father used to make in his younger days in this part of the country it is called a "Scout Gun" We make them yet. First a quill is got + cut as long as it allows, then a bit of a stick + it is made so that it runs smoothly through the quill. It is charged in a potatoe. Putting a potato into the big end + when it is coming out of the little end it makes a slight noise. It is great pastime in our house shooting at one + other out of these guns. We make many other toys also which our father taught us, tops, butter fly cages + Scout Guns, are not likely to go out of fashion for they are only being revived. This is one of the many toys which are made in homes to day.[-]Spinning top, First of all a thread spool is got and pared at one end of it well until it is made like the shape of a top then get a piece of a stick about 2 inches in length and pare it until it is smooth and a sharp top on it then it is put through the hole in the top and boys and girls spin it. All country children find spinning this top is a great pastime.
(continues on next page)

4658462/4657985/4660676.title: Homemade Toys
4658462/4657985/4660676.text: Children find great amusement in making toys, but it is not often you will see children with patience to make toys now, for their Mother's or friends by them for them. But in Ancient Ireland there was no "Machinery" to make toys, so the children made their own toys themselves. They delighted in making them. Many Girls and Boys in their spare time like to make toys.Little Girls likes to make daisy chains especially for May day. They have these as a girdle or wristlets. Boys made tops from thread-spools, guns stuffed with paper made from the middle of an "Elder Berry Bush. Often the boys made a bird-cradle to trap birds. Grandma say's when she was young the children used to make gread models from turnips such as little women and men and cutting out cups and jugs and so on to play house. I asked he about how the children made balls to play with and she said, that they used to gather daisies or any wild flowers, roll them up, and tie a string to it and bounce it she says there there was good fun with these toys.

4658419/4653143/4660728.title: Homemade Toys
4658419/4653143/4660728.text: In my district small boys and girls generally make toys during their pastime.Some of the toys girls enjoy making are dolls made from rags and shavings.  First they make they shape of a body with cloth and stuff it with rags.  They then make a round lump from rags or shavings and cover it with nice white cloth.  All they have to do then is paint two eyes a mouth and a nose in the face and their doll is completed.Boys find amusement in making toy guns from elder branches.  They get a piece about twelve inches long and scoop it out from end to end and cut out a square about 4 inches from one side of it.  They then get a piece on side of it.  They then get a piece of steel and put the two ends into the 4 inch hole.  Their gun is then completed.

4658462/4658016/4660875.title: Homemade Toys - A Scout Gun
4658462/4658016/4660875.text: The home mad toy which takes the lead on our house is a toy which my father used to make in his young days. In this part of the country it is called a "Scout Gun". We make them yet. First a quill is got and cut as long as it allows then a bit of stick and it is made so that it runs smoothly through the quill. It is charged with a potato. Putting a potato in at the big end and when it is coming out on the little end it makes a noise. It is a great pastime in our house shooting at one and other of these guns. We make many other toys also which our father taught us and are not likely to go out of fashion for they are only being revived. This is one of many toys which are made in homes today. (fig.)

4662105/4657255/4662168.title: Homemade Toys
4662105/4657255/4662168.text:
My father told me that when he was a small boy he very often made spinning tops from spools or pieces of wood. With a pen-knife he cut away one end of the spool and pointed it. He made it smooth and fine by rubbing it to a rough sand-stone. With a nail he [scored?] out the track for the spinning cord. The cord itself was made of flax and a small piece of leather shaped like a penny was tied at the end of the string to prevent it slipping when the top would be a spinning.In his grandfather's time he says spoons for eating eggs were made from pieces of wood. These when made were called crainsceens and were only used for a short time. It was very difficult to keep them clean so they were burned and fresh ones made in a rough and ready fashion. Wooden mugs were also made and used for drinking purposes and for eating
(continues on next page)

4605947/4605015/4662314.title: Hooping-Cough
4605947/4605015/4662314.text:
Hooping CoughA husband and wife of the same surname have the cure of the Hooping cough. They lead the person that has the Hooping cough by the hand to a place where three rivers meet the three mere waters. And, with the water from the three mere waters, they make the sign of the Cross three times on the patients head. The performance is repeated for three days. The cure is made on Tuesdays and Thursdays.Bridget Loughlin (Pupil)Derrinahona,Dowra,Co. LeitrimFrom Mrs Ellie Loughlin (49 yrs)Derrinahona,Dowra,Co. Leitrim.



Home made toysIn olden times boys and girls used to make fifes. They used to cut a straight stick about a foot long, put a hole down through the centre with a hot iron and put six small round holes down the side and a bigger one near the top into which they used blow air. The girls used to make bracelets with lips that grew on the wild-rose. They used get a needle and thread and hole the lips through the centre the needle. Then the used put the lips on the
(continues on next page)

4666590/4664416/4667440.title: Homemade Toys
4666590/4664416/4667440.text:
Long ago people made their own toys as there were no factories.Here is the picture of a home-made golliwog made from pieces of woollen thread tied and decorated with woollen threads.Little girls made their own dolls out of little bags of cloth which they stuffed with straw or sawdust from the local carpenter's shop. The bag to represent the head was stuffed with rags. The eyes nose and mouth were drawn with coloured
(continues on next page)

4666572/4663082/4667509.title: Homemade Toys
4666572/4663082/4667509.text: In ancient times the children made their own toys. They made dolls from potatoes and sticks. They put two potatoes together, one for the head and the other for the body and sticks for the legs and hands. They made spinning tops from blocks of timber. The girls used to go out and pick leaves of cabbage and decorate them with flowers and feathers and wear them as hats. The girls made necklaces from daisies and thread. They used to go teaching the dock leaves as scholars. They also played gobs and pennies and buttons. The boys also made cars from timber and four polish boxes as wheels. A top was made from a spool, a water gun from elder, a crib from rods as traps for birds.Long ago children used to make crosses out of card board and ribbon at the corners and in the centre and wear them on the shoulders on St. Patrick's day.

4666593/4665042/4667512.title: Homemade Toys
4666593/4665042/4667512.text:
In Winter I amuse myself making catapults to kill birds during the Winter days. In making a catapult I first get a strong twig fork and I then cut notches on the top of the prongs of the fork in order that the cords would hold the rubber firmly to the fork. Then after this I get two strips of rubber and I tie them on to each prong of the fork. Then I get a piece of leather and I put two holes in it for the rubber to go through. I then put the strips of rubber through the holes of the leather and tie them. I then put a stone into the leather and I catch the fork in one hand and the leather and stone in the other. I then strain the rubbers and when I have them strained I let go the leather and then the stone will shoot out of it. The strain of the rubbers will drive the stone a long distance
(continues on next page)

4666593/4665058/4667591.title: Homemade Toys
4666593/4665058/4667591.text:
Another toy I make at home is a potato-gun. This is how I make it. First I get a quill of a goose called the "barrel" and a stick called the "ram-rod". Then I get a slice of a potato and drive the quill down through it and a piece of the potato will remain stuck in the quill. Then I stick the other end of the quill down through the potato and a piece of the potato will be in the two ends then. Then I stick the ram-rod through one end and that drives one of the pieces of the potato and it hits the other piece and drives it off with a sound. The ram-rod must be shorter than the quill so that it will not drive out the two pieces at the same time. When I am putting in the pieces of potatoes it is called "loading the barrel".A sling is made in the following way. First I get a piece of leather and two pieces of cords. I made
(continues on next page)

4666596/4665442/4667957.title: Homemade Toys
4666596/4665442/4667957.text:
Long ago the children used to make several toys, but now it is very seldom you would see a home-made toy, because the toys you would buy in the shop are much nicer.The principal toys made by the girls are a nice cap made from bulrushes; a nice belt made from sweet-papers; a chain made from daisies; and nice crosses for St. Patrick's day.The daisy chain is made by picking about twenty daisies and stringing them together with a needle and thread in the shape of a necklace. The nice cross for St. Patrick's day is made with a card-board and nice coloured ribbons. First they cut the card-board in the shape of a cross, and then they stitch on the ribbons.They can also make nice belts with the papers that are wrapped around the sweets.
(continues on next page)

4666602/4665848/4668012.title: Homemade Toys
4666602/4665848/4668012.text:
This is how we make tops. First of all we get a round piece of timber and pare it so that one end is pointed and the other remains flat. Then a piece of steel, called a spear, is driven into the top at the pointed end and it is on this spear that the top spins. To spin a top a long cord is needed. The cord is twisted round the pointed part of the top. The end of the cord is tied round the lúidín and the top is held between the thumb and the other four fingers. Then it is thrown on the ground, spear foremost, and the unwinding of the cord causes the top to spin. A very interesting game is played with tops. A ring about two feet in diameter is made on the road and one top is laid down on the road about twenty yards away from the ring. At the start of the game all those who are to take part "peg" for a small stone on the road and the boy who is farthest away puts down his top first. Then each boy spins his top in turn, takes it up on his hand while still spinning and hits the top on the ground in the direction of the ring. If any boy fails to do this he has to lay down his top on the ground and the other boy takes up his top. The top is placed in the exact spot in
(continues on next page)

4666607/4666263/4668023.title: Homemade Toys
4666607/4666263/4668023.text: There are a lot of home made toys.There is a toy called the tractor. it is made of a reel with rubber going through the reel. A piece of candle with a hole through which the rubber is put. a piece of a stitch is attached to the rubbera catapult is madefrom a piece of a stick, rubber and a piece of leather tied on. It is made for throwing stones.

4666584/4664011/4668048.title: Homemade Toys
4666584/4664011/4668048.text: There is a little boy living in Ballylongford named Rodger Boyle and he is very good for painting and making coloured pictures. Mostly all the little girls make hats and chairs from rushes. There is a man in Tarbert by the name of Walter Fitzell and he can make any kind of an article with timber. He made a horse with a man on his back and he jumping a gate, and several other things. In the parish of Ballylongford there is a man by the name of John Donavan and he can make every kind of a small toy for his children. Long ago people were able to make many home made toys. Such as making a basket of twigs. First they would boil the twigs, and when they would be boiled they would be soft and then they would make a basket from them. The boys make whips of rushes and play tops and they make marbles of small turnips or potatoes. Children pull rushes and felestrumes and make boats of them and put them floating on the river. Long ago the children used to make Teetotalums they used to put on it P. A. N. T. They used to put money on the table and they used to spin Teetotalums on the table. If P. turned up they would have to put down a penny. If A. turned up he could take it all. If N. turned up he could take nothing. If T. turned up he could take one penny.

4672105/4670689/4673120.title: Homemade Toys
4672105/4670689/4673120.text:
Long ago people made many different toys at home. in Winter the girls made dolls from rags which they dressed and adorned themselves. In Summer they made daisy chains. In Winter most of the toys were manufactured. The boys made bird-cradles from rods for the purpose of catching birds. They aslo made snares from snare wire for catching rabbits. These tow trades are carrie don in almost every county place at present. Boys made spinning tops from spools which had no thread on them and with these they amused themselves spinning but those are rarely made now. Boys also made and still make guns from a piece of elder stick and rubber and they also made slings. Hurleys are made from ash trees It is only to shape it like a hurley and clean it until it is nice for holding in your hand. They also made a ball from worsted wool rooled tightly round a cork. Almost every boy make those things himself. Lorries and cars are toys that
(continues on next page)

4672089/4669184/4678655.title: Homemade Toys
4672089/4669184/4678655.text: Home Made ToysNearly every boy and many girls find amusement in making toys.  Nowadays girls string flowers together and this they call a daisy chain.Up to this day boys make toys out of thread spools, spouting guns from elder branches.  They make bird cradles out of sally rods.  With which they trap birds.  Boys make snares out of wire.  With these they catch rabbits and hares.Models from turnips are made by scooping the shape of two eyes and a mouth out of a turnip.  A candle is then put in to it and it shows like a man's head in the dark.Few of these amusements are carried on nowadays.  My elder brothers often made these toys when young.

4672090/4669216/4678755.title: Homemade Toys
4672090/4669216/4678755.text: Nearly every boy and many girls find amusement in making toys. Nowadays, girls string flowers together, and, this they call a daisy chain.Up to this day boys make toys out of empty thread-spools, and spouting guns from elder branches. They make bird-cradles out of sally rods, with which they trap birds.Models from turnips are made by scooping the shape of two eyes and a mouth out of a turnip. A candle is then put into it, and it shows like a man's head int he dark. Few of these amusements are carried on nowadays.Patrick's crosses are made from paper, decorated with different coloured ribbons, and worn on the right shoulder by little girls on St Patrick's Day.Little girls sometimes make rag dolls, which they dress up "as if they were bought in the shops.

4666588/4664341/4678978.title: Homemade Toys
4666588/4664341/4678978.text:
Many years ago toys were scarce and simply made. A woman of ninety years of age showed me a doll belonging to her grandmother. She treasures it and promises to leave it to me when she is dying.In summer, in the days gone by, little girls spent many hours picking rushes.Out of these rushes they made little hats which they called "Cubnín Cub". When the hat was finished, flowers were put around the crowns.Then a "bastún" was made from 12 very long rushes, tied together with another long rush.When the Cubnín Cub and bastún were finished, the little girls marched round the field singing merrily.
(continues on next page)

4672099/4669914/4681764.title: Local Cures
4672099/4669914/4681764.text:
(continued from previous page)
supposed the fever will be gone after two weeks. The cure of a nettle burn is to rub the slimy stuff of a docken leaf on it and it will ease the pain.



Some boys and girls spend a good part of their time making toys such as water guns and candle sticks and candles. The water guns were made by getting a stick about eight inches in length with a soft centre in it and then scraping out the soft stuff in the the centre so that nothing is left but the shell. Then get another thinner bit of a stick and tie a piece of wool on the end of it and put it up in the other stick out of which the centre was taken not forgetting to leave some of the soft stuff in the end and a small hole in it.
(continues on next page)

4672099/4669917/4681782.title: Homemade Toys
4672099/4669917/4681782.text:
(continued from previous page)
