5009332/5007702/5131439.text:
At Christmas nearly all boys and girls visit the town to buy some toys to play with In their spare time they play with them and amuse themselves This is only nowadays but when our Fathers and Mothers were young toys were not as easy to be got. It was necessary for children then to make their own toys for example,Boys made popgun and buzzers. Girls made necklaces with chessnuts and also a magic lantern. Popguns were made thus. A chestnut branch was secured A hole was cut in it and the pith was taken out.When this way done two pieces of paper were chewed. These were stuck in at each end of the branch. Then a stick called a ram rod was got and this was thrust in the place where
(continues on next page)

5009260/5002494/5131833.title: Customs at Weddings
5009260/5002494/5131833.text:
(continued from previous page)
breakfast which is usually prepared by a friend.  After breakfast they have music, and dancing.  All friends and relations are invited to the wedding.The pair go away for a short holiday the morning on which they were married.It is said that if it rains on the morning of the wedding the Bride will cry all her life long.Madge Browne11 Maudlin TownWexford



When the boys want to make marbles they go down to a marl hole at the side of the railway and get a mussy substance to make the marbles.It is yellow and they wet it to make it soft so that they can roll it to the shape of the marbles.  When soft the marl is wet and rolled in to marbles it is put into a sunny place to dry.  But the boys are not as pleased with these as they are with the glass marbles.

5009260/5002498/5131878.title: Homemade Marbles
5009260/5002498/5131878.text: When the young boys are short of money to buy the shop marbles they go down on the railway line where there is a marl-hole on the bank.They dig a small hole and get a quantity of the yellow mud which is called yellow marl.  This they roll between their hands until it is a number of small balls and lay them aside to dry in the sun.Afterwards when these are dry they are ready for use.

5009260/5002506/5131916.title: How Shoes are Made from Rushes
5009260/5002506/5131916.text:
(continued from previous page)
and over-sew it and they keep on doing this laying one rush on top of the other.  They keep on putting the rushes on in this manner until it is long enough to stretch up to the ankle, they knit a long strip and they sew it on to the back and bring it around to fasten on the instep.  The cardboard sole will not last very long but according as the sole wears, they stitch on another.Maureen Murphy111 FaytheWexford



The boys use the hollow stalk of a weed called hogweed.  They stuff one end with paper to make a whistle. Then with a penknife they make a notch or split down the centre of the stalk when they blow through it the wind is stopped by the paper and has to escaped through the split and as it does so it makes a whistling sound.  The harder it is blown the louder it seems.
(continues on next page)

5009025/4978648/5131983.title: Homemade Toys
5009025/4978648/5131983.text: Different sorts of toys such as tops and whistles are made at home in this district.  Tops are made from empty spools.  One end of the spools chopped thin.  Then a nail is hammered through the spool to make the spike.  A whistle is made from a piece of sycamore tree about four inches long and three-quarter inch wide.  The skin is taken off without breaking it.  A hole is then made in the stick.  Then the skin is put back on the stick and arranged is such a way that when you blow into it, it will make a whistle.

5009025/4978649/5131995.title: Homemade Toys
5009025/4978649/5131995.text:
Up till a couple of years ago toy guns were made from elder sticks.The gun-maker got a piece of elder stick and a bit of bull wire.  He then bored the centre out of the stick with the wire.  Then he packed a piece of turnip into one end and blew into the other end and packed another into the other end without letting the air out.  He then got a piece of rod and pushed it against the piece he put in last.  The wind which was blown into it before blew out the piece of turnip at the other end and made a shot.Other toys were also made in this district such as bows and arrows and riddle cages.  The bows and arrows were easily made because all had to be procured was a fairly strong stick and a piece of cord.The cord was tied to the stick so that when it was pulled it sprang back.  Another stick was got and pointed.  This was the arrow.
(continues on next page)

5009290/5005019/5132883.title: Homemade Toys
5009290/5005019/5132883.text:
Home - Made - ToysLong ago the toys were not sold as cheap as the toys of today are sold, people used to make home - made toys for their childrenThey used make rattle - boxes, from rushes and put stones or beads inside to make the rattle, for the youngster.They used to make animals of every shape from cloth stuffed with horse-hair, and they used make dolls stuffed with old rags as well.The children used make spinning tops from empty cotton reels, pared to represent the top and a wooden peg passed through the hole in the centre.  They would make a whip, with which to spin the top, from twine or pieces of cord knotted together and attached to the end of a stick.Girls used to make daisy-chains and use them as necklaces, crowns and girdles.Boys used to amuse themselves by making snap-cradles to catch birds.  These cradles would have a thistle or some tit-bit on it in order to attract the birds attention.
(continues on next page)

5009298/5005598/5133339.title: Homemade Toys
5009298/5005598/5133339.text:
212Home Made ToysAll children made necklaces out of daisies.  They put a wee hole in the top of the daisy.  When they draw the other daisy up through the hole.  They plait a whip with rushes and then they tie the top and bottom with a piece of cord.  They plait a rattle-box out of five rushes and they put two or three stones in it to make a rattle.  If it is left in a place for a short time it will wither away but if it is rubbed with lard or grease it will not wither away.  Girls make dresses out of pieces of silk or cotton.  They also make bed-clothes for their dolls
(continues on next page)

5009298/5005600/5133344.title: Homemade Toys
5009298/5005600/5133344.text: Boys and girls make toys for themselves when they are young.  Girls make dolls out of paper and put sticks for legs and arms.  They plait backets and rattle-boxes out of rushes.They make backets to carry flowers.They put stones in the rattle-box to make a rattle.  The boys make tops for spinning.  They make them out of spools.  They pare one end of the spool then they get a stick and put it in the hole then they spin with it.

5009298/5005601/5133347.title: Homemade Toys
5009298/5005601/5133347.text: Most of the boys and girls make their own toys in this country.  They get six long rushes and plait them into a basket  The boys makes their own toys and their is one toy which every boy make and it is called a "cleeveen".  They catch birds in it.

5009298/5005602/5133351.title: Homemade Toys
5009298/5005602/5133351.text: Boys and girls around this country make a lot of toys during their spare time.  Making a whistle out of a chest-nut first they get the chest-nut and a knife and cut a hole in it and clean it out well and when they have it cleaned out well and when they have it cleaned it is a whistle.  Another one is making baskets out of rushes.First thing they get five rushes all the same length.  Then they plait them one over the other and when they have it finished they put one round the handle to make it strong.

5009298/5005603/5133354.title: Homemade Toys
5009298/5005603/5133354.text:
217Boys and girls round this country make a lot of toys at home in their spare time.  Making baskets with rushes is a very common one.  They get five long rushes, but they all must be the same length.  Then they plait the rushes over one another and when the basket is plaited up to the handle they get two rushes and tie them around the basket to make it strong.Another toy that is usually made by girls is making dresses for dolls.  Boys also make catapults for killing birds.  They get a piece of a strong stick and then they get a thick rubber and tie it to the stick when it is made.  Boys also make rattle-boxes.  Children make whips which are sometimes very useful to the people of the house.They get three strong rushes and plait the three of them together and when it
(continues on next page)

5009298/5005604/5133363.title: Homemade Toys
5009298/5005604/5133363.text:
(continued from previous page)
is plaited they tie a cord at the top.Boys also make spinning-tops out of empty spools.  They pare one side of the spool very thin and put a sharp top on it.



Boys and girls in this country make a a lot of toys in their spare time.Some of them make rattle-boxes by getting six rushes the same length and plait them together and when they are plaited they have them made they
(continues on next page)

5009298/5005605/5133366.title: Homemade Toys
5009298/5005605/5133366.text:
(continued from previous page)
put a stone in it.  Some of the girls make doll's dresses and doll's shoes out of cloth.  The boys make spinning tops out of spools.



Boys and girls around they like to be making toys of ther own girls make little dresses for dolls and knit little caps and shoes for their dolls.They have a little basket of their own to hold their little bits of material and scissors thimbles and needles.  They make the basket out of rushes.  They make
(continues on next page)

5009305/5006043/5133393.title: Homemade Toy
5009305/5006043/5133393.text: 38Home made toyChildren made daisy chains and hung them round their necks.Cowslips made into balls was another childish playElder tree branches made grand pop guns.Wheat or oat stalk made whistles with the aid of a pen knife.Children used to make dolls out of rags, and their fathers and mothers used to make them dolls out of sticks.Catapults are made from a piece of leather and a bit rubber string.  Bows and arrows made from the yew bough.Birds were made from potatoes with a feather or two for the tail and sticks for legs were made.Dolls houses and baby houses were made from attractive bits of china or delph.Gooseberries with thorns for legs and arms.  A "booraun" is a sieve but with skin bottom and used for making bread in.  A booraun placed side ways on a piece of stick catches birds in snowy weather.Eleanor O'Connor. Caim N.S. Enniscorthy Given by her grandmother Mrs Hibbett residing at Kiltrea Ho. Enniscorthy

5009288/5004844/5133492.title: Composition - Homemade Toys
5009288/5004844/5133492.text:
In the old days people used to make toys at home for their children.  Some people were able to make a teetum-totam out of a spool.  They made four sides on it and put or cut the words on it - "Take all",  "Put all",  "Put one",  and "Take two".  It was made something like this.- Drawing of teetum-totam -People used to make snares for catching rats long ago.  They were made from a bit of a sally rod with the two ends of it stuck in the ground and a piece of leather on one of the ends made in the shape of a snare.  When the rat would run into it one part of it pulled up and the rat was choked.Another toy that used to be made was a rush-whip.  The way that it was made was - they would get three
(continues on next page)

5009295/5005337/5133610.title: Homemade Toys
5009295/5005337/5133610.text:
190Home - Made Toys.TopsMy father is able to make pegging -tops.  He makes them out of a block of wood about three inches by two.  He has a lathe which is driven by a wheel.  When the top is cut out he makes a spike about two inches long.  He sharpens the ends of the spike and he drives one of the ends into the top.  He leaves the spike sticking out about one inch.Catapult.A catapult is made out of a forked stick, two rubber bands and a small piece of leather[diagram of catapult]The rubber bands are tied to the forked stick and they are tied to the leather also.Put a stone in the leather, pull back the leather towards the end of the forked stick and let go the leather.  The stone will fly out.  Boys use a catapult to shoot stones at birds.A slingA sling is made of out two fairly long cords & a piece of leather.  There are two
(continues on next page)

5009295/5005339/5133616.title: Homemade Toys
5009295/5005339/5133616.text: 192Home - Made ToysWind-millsThere was an old man who used to travel round the country about 1908 selling windmills.  He used to make these windmills himself.  Children bought these windmills for a half-penny.  If they had no money he would take a bone, or rags, or bottles instead.  He made these windmills out of sticks.Daisy - ChainWhen the fields are full of daisies we make daisy-chains.  We get one daisy, and make a hole in it, and put another daisy in that hole [ in the stalk ].  We keep on doing this until the daisy-chain is big enough to go around our neck.TurnipWhen it comes near Christmas some people get a turnip.  They cut out in it, a nose, two eyes and a mouth;  they put a candle down in the turnip.  They light the candle before they put it down in the turnip.Whipping TopsMr Dan Hayden of Ballytreacy, Boolavogue, Ferns, Co Wexford makes whipping tops.  We get a stick, tie a bit of cord on to it, and whip the top.Elizabeth Armstrong, Boolavogue, Ferns, Co Wexford.These stories were told to me by my mother :-Mrs E. Armstrong.

5009295/5005340/5133625.title: Homemade Toys
5009295/5005340/5133625.text: 193Home Made Toys.A Snare.A snare is made with snare-wire.  There is a loop on the end of the wire.  Snares are used for catching rabbits.  They are set on the rabbit's path.  A stick is stuck in the ground to hold the rabbit.When the rabbit is running along the path he runs his head into the snare, and is choked.Trap for birds.Dig a hole in snow and put a pot-lid over the whole, but prop the lid up with a stick thus :-[diagram of trap]Tie a long cord to the stick.  Put bread in the hole. When the bird goes in for the bread I pull the cord, the lid falls down, and the bird is caught.RattlesMy father often made rattles out of rushes.  He got some rushes and tied the bottom of the rushes.  Then he plaited the rushes up to the top, and he put a stone in it.  When this was shaken it would rattle.Gerard Lacey,Carrigeen, Ferns, Co Wexford.These stories were told to me by my fatherMr Michael Lacey  (48 yrs)[same address]

5009295/5005341/5133640.title: Homemade Toys
5009295/5005341/5133640.text: 194Home - Made ToysA topA toy that I often saw made is a top.  A spool is pared at one end.  Then a stick (like a pencil in shape) is put through the hole in the spool.  The stick is pared at the end also.  The top is now finished, and will spin.DollI often saw a home-made doll.  One of these dolls I saw was a knitted one.  The head, eyes, ears, hands, arms, legs and feet were shaped into it.  It was knitted in several different colours.  When made it was stuffed with saw-dust and sewn together.  I have also seen teddy-bears, and many other little toys knitted and stuffed in this way.(diagram of the spool-top)Mary Breen,Kilcoulshea, Boolavogue, Ferns,Co Wexford.

5009295/5005342/5133644.title: Homemade Toys
5009295/5005342/5133644.text: 195Home Made ToysA topMy father made tops out of a piece of a small square stick.  He put a hole down through the middle of the stickOn each of the four sides of the top were letters.  A was put on one side, N on another, P and H on the remaining sides.  When he and his chums started to play they would get someone to open the top.  They played for buttons.  If A turned up that meant to take all.  If N turned up that meant you were to get none.  If H turned up you were to get only half.  If P turned up you were to put downThese stories were told to me by my fatherMr Patrick Carbery,  (66)Carrigeen, Ferns, Co Wexford.John Carbery  [same address]

5009281/5004276/5133673.title: Homemade Toys
5009281/5004276/5133673.text:
Some years ago the people made their own toys.  The rattle was a very common home made toy.  It was made from rushes.  The rushes were plaited in the shape of a rattle box and a little bell was placed inside the rushes.Another of the ancient toys was the home basket.  It was made from rushes.  The rushes were plaited in the shape of a basket."Rag dolls" are made also.  They are made out of old rags.  You would make a ball of rags and stitch them togetherYou would get a pencil and mark in the eyes, nose + mouth.  You would get an other rag and tuck it.  You would then stitch the body and head together"Necklets" are made out of ten or fifteen berries off a dog rose bush and push a needle and
(continues on next page)

5009323/5007095/5133913.title: Homemade Toys
5009323/5007095/5133913.text:
Long ago, very few children went to the expense of buying toys.  They got their fathers to make them for them, or if they were able they made them themselves.  They made dolls and guns and were very fond of making tops.  They made a very effective sort of weapon which was called a "pop-gun".  These were made from long hollow reeds which are to be found near the river.  A length was cut from these reeds and cleaned out inside.  This was the gun.  The ammunition consisted of haws which were got from the sceac.  The haws were pushed into one end of the gun and the gun was placed in the mouth and the haws blown out through the other end.  The men long ago made slings for their boys and showed them how to use them.  The sling consisted of a long leather band, very wide in the centre and narrower at each end.  A round stone was placed in the broad part and each end was bent round it.  The two ends were caught in the hand, and the sling whirled round.  One of the ends are suddenly released and the stone flies on it's way.There are some old men in this town at the present day who are experts with sling.Long ago the men were experts for making
(continues on next page)

5009307/5006165/5133935.title: Homemade Toys
5009307/5006165/5133935.text: 160Home Made ToysBots often made tops from thread spools.  First they cut one end of the spool and then they sharpened that end and it was made then.Guns were made from elder branches.  First the heart is driven out by means of a narrow bar, then a little ball of paper is put in one end.  Then if the stick is given a sudden push it will be a great shot.Boys also make bird traps.  First they put some dry coaxing food on the ground for the birds and put a stick down into the ground ( which must be very weak) Then they balance a large basket on a stick.  A long piece of cord must be tied out of the basket, so when the bird is enjoying is enjoying herself under the basket, just pull the cord and the basket will fall on the bird, so she can be caught.A lot of boys make snares now -a-days for catching hares and rabbits.  The wire is twisted first and then a loop is put on it, and then it is set on a rabbit path.  When the rabbit will run along the path she will run her head into it and choke herself.Name:  Victor Gainfort.

5009312/5006459/5133976.title: Homemade Toys
5009312/5006459/5133976.text:
I often made nice toys during my spare time such as a top, dolls furniture and turnip models     To make a top I pared an empty reel until I had four sides on it, that is, shaped something like a pencil. I then got a small bit of stick just large enough to go through the hole in the reel, and I put a sharp point on one end of it so that it could spin nicely.     When I had the top completed , I got a pencil and on each of the four sides i put a letter;-A.N.T.P. which means "all", "none", "take one",  "put one". Which ever letter turned up ,when the top stopped spinning, I decided what was to be done.     Once I made a doll's bed, chair and table  from small pieces of wood. A bed is made by getting about ten pieces of light wood , four fairly strong pieces to complete the head and foot and two pieces just fastened to those to have the main part of this made. When this was done I got two long pieces to make each side of the bed and when those were nailed to the sides I just placed  two laths on the bottom. I had my doll's bed completed then.     A doll's chair is still harder to make than a bed. Once I said  I would try my skill and see if I could make a chair. I had a look round at large chairs so  I started, I picked up every small piece of wood I could find. I got two long sticks for the back legs of the chair and two other short pieces for the front legs. I then got four light bits of laths to go between the legs to keep the chair steady.
(continues on next page)

5009312/5006461/5133995.title: Homemade Toys
5009312/5006461/5133995.text: I can make many nice toys during my spare time like rag dolls, doll's  furniture, daisy chains, and string beads  together to make necklaces.     I made a lovely rag doll from a pieceof material, which my mother had left over when making dresses. Then i sewed this in the form of a bag. I put small bits of material into it to make the body. I then made a hard little ball to form the head,which i covered with a  white cloth . I sewed this part to the body. The legs and the body still remained to be made.     I got bits of material and sewed them  to the body, these made the legs and arms. I made the legs, eyes, nose and mouth with black thread. For the hair I stuck black wool on the head. I then made many nice dresses for her.     To make a doll's dresser: get the inside of a match box and stand it upright. Then cut out the sides of the lid, into wide strips, these represent shelves. Then smear some glue to the sides of the shelf, this helps it to stick to the inside of the dresser. Then the dresser is made.     The making of a doll's dresser is very easy. Get the inside of a match box. The inner part is turned upside down so that the opening is facing downwards. Then cut nice thin strips and glue them to the four corners to make the legs of the table.

5009303/5005917/5134018.title: Homemade Toys
5009303/5005917/5134018.text: 235Home Made ToysMost toys were home made long ago.  Boys can still make tops from spools, whistles from a piece of sycamore tree and yo-yo's from polish boxes, buzzers were also made from leather and some string.  The only game was horse-shoes

5009312/5006462/5134022.title: Homemade Toys
5009312/5006462/5134022.text: I often made toys such as a catapult, a sling,a bow and arrow and other toys. I would like to describe some of them.       To make a catapult , a fork shaped is needed and two narrow strips of rubber almost a foot long. A fairly large piece of leather is attached to the rubber on each end and the rubber is fastened to the fork stick. Then the catapult is made. I can throw stones out of the catapult  by holding the stick in one hand,  and by putting a stone in the leather part, and by pulling back the rubber with the other hand, and then by letting it go suddenly the stone flies.     A toy bow and arrow is made from a sally stick bent and fastened with a cord. The arrow is made from a forked stick which is held on the cord. The cord and arrow are pulled back and then let go, and the arrow goes off with great force.     A small wheel-barrow is made from a box, two fairly thick sticks for handles and a wooden wheel fastened in front. The box is nailed on the sticks and then the barrow is made.     Rabbit Snares: I have often made snares to catch rabbits. I cut six pieces of snaring wire and twist them together. Then I put a loop  on one end of it so that it can pull close on the rabbit. I fasten a strong piece of cord to the other end of the wire and I get a piece of stick called a "snibby"to put in the ground to hold the snare on the rabbit path.

5009312/5006463/5134039.title: Homemade Toys
5009312/5006463/5134039.text: In my spare time I often make doll's furniture, and rag dolls and cars.     To make a doll's dresser, get a match box and put the inside part standing up on the lid. Then get three or four pieces of slender card-board to make to make the shelves and the dresser  is made.     To make a rag doll, roll tightly together a piece of cloth to make the body of the doll, and sew two pieces of sticks to each side to make the arms. To make the head roll a small piece of white cloth together and stitch it to the body. I made the eyes, nose and mouth with black thread.      To make a horse's car get a square piece of wood and four long slender pieces, and nail these down on the sides of the car. Then get two long thick sticks and nail them to the body of the car so as to make the shafts.     Making toys is a great pastime for either boys or girls. Boys are fond of making stilts,bird cages, bow and arrows. and girls are very fond of making doll's furniture, doll's dresses and making kites.The furniture is easily made with match boxes and card-boards.     Kites are a great past time for flying on windy days, especially when the wind is high,

5009321/5006974/5134537.title: Homemade Toys
5009321/5006974/5134537.text: 21225-2-38Home made toysThese are some of the toys made by boys at home : tops,  The tops are made from a spoolie pared into a point at one end with a bit of a stick run through it.Buzzers are made from the lid of a polish box and it is cut into little teeth around the outside and two holes put in the middle of it and a cord run through the holes.Propellors are made from a bit of a stick with both ends pared off it and a hole bored through the middle of it and a nail driven through the hole into the top of a pole.The leaping doll is made from a ball-bearing wrapped up in silver paper.Waterwheels are made from two boards sawed out round with a fret-saw, and a couple of bits of sticks put between the two round boards and an axle run through it and then it is put in a stream where there is a fall coming down on it.Joe Rothwell  (13)Ballyregan,Ferns,  Co. Wexford

5009321/5006980/5134552.title: Homemade Toys
5009321/5006980/5134552.text: 2181-6-38HomemadetoysThe toys that we make at home are gollywogs and daisy necklaces.The way you make a daisy necklace is you make a hole in the stalk of one daisy and pull the stalk of another daisy through the hole and so on.When you are making a golliwog you wrap wool around a matchbox a few times then take it off and cut the bottom and the top of the wool then tie it in the middle : you make it with coloured threadSusie Rynhart  (13)Ballyfoley,Co. Wexford

5009322/5007045/5134739.title: Homemade Toys
5009322/5007045/5134739.text:
283Home made toysThe girls make chains out of daisies and quicken berries and buttercups and dog briars.The daisy chain is made by slitting the end of the daisy and putting the other daily through it and the buttercup chain is made in the same way.The quicken-berry chain is made by getting a needle and thread and putting the thread through the berriesThe dog briar chain is made in the same way.When the chains are made the girls wear them around their necks for necklaces.The boys make snares for rabbits and they also make pop guns.They also make snares for birds.  The snare for the birds is a can  with one side held off the ground by a short stick to which a cord tied.  Food is placed behind the stick.When the bird comes to the food the cord is pulled and the bird is trapped underneath the can
(continues on next page)

5044716/5034110/5135075.title: Homemade Toys
5044716/5034110/5135075.text:
Long ago when our grand-fathers and fathers were children they had no toys to play with except home home-made toys. Now we get lovely toys in the shops. Some of the toys I will write about. Whistles made from a stick. Get a stick about three or four inches long with the bark taken off and put a hole in it and a place to put your mouth on. When it is blown it makes a nice whistle. Spinning tops are made from spools. Two spinning tops can be made from one spool. The spool is cut in the middle, then it is paired to a point at one end and a short piece of a stick is put in to the hole. It is spun
(continues on next page)

5044716/5034112/5135077.title: Homemade Toys
5044716/5034112/5135077.text:
Long ago the children were not used to toys and they made toys for themselves.One of the toys they made was a whistle. It was made from a piece of an ash stick about two inches long. The stick is cut and the bark has to be loosened and screwed off with the hand, the stick has to be wet, then put on the bark again. Cut a hole in the side as far as the split. Then the whistle is ready for use.A motor, It was made with a couple of little boards, and for wheels they used lids of polish boxes.For a horse they got up on a stool.
(continues on next page)

5044716/5034113/5135079.title: Homemade Toys
5044716/5034113/5135079.text:
(continued from previous page)
A pop-gun. For a pop-gun they got a piece of an elder stick about four inches long and bore a hole right through it. Put a piece of paper into the hole and shoot it out with a smaller piece of stick.



Whistles:- These are also called "killy-corns". Get a straw with a knot on the end of it. Put a split under the knot and blow. If it will not play then, the person says, "killy-corn, killy-corn if you don't play I'll cut off your head and throw you away"Pop-gun. Get an elder stick and take the "middle" out of it. Get a stick that will go through the middle. Put bits of paper into the hole and shoot them out with the stick.

5044716/5034114/5135081.title: Homemade Toys
5044716/5034114/5135081.text:
When i have nothing to do, when I am at home I make play-toys. The way I make a "pop gun". I get a thick lump of a stick and get a red hot iron and bore a hole through the stick. I get a thin piece of a stick then, and stuff a piece of wet paper in the hole and shove the thin stick quickly and the paper flies out. The "jenny-spinner" is like a top. It get a spool and a good sharp knife. Pare both sides till you come to the middle. Then break off. Get a thin piece of a stick and put it down in the hole of the spool and point the top of the stick sharply. Then catch the stick in your fingers and spin round.
(continues on next page)

5044716/5034116/5135088.title: Homemade Toys
5044716/5034116/5135088.text:
In olden times when there were no toys sold in shops, the children used make toys themselves. They used to make whistles from straw. They got the straw and cut a bit out of the side of it and when blew through it, it whistled. They also made whistles out of sticks. They used get a bit of a stick bore a hole through it and cut a bit out of the side of it and then blow. They made a car out of a box with four polish boxes under it for wheels. For wheelbarrows they used get a box and put a polish-box on it for a wheel  and put two handles out of it. For handballs they would get paper and roll it up into a
(continues on next page)

5009339/5008500/5135144.title: Homemade Toys
5009339/5008500/5135144.text: My uncle made "a dancing master" for us when we were children. It was a replica of one his father (died 1895) used to make. It was carved with a pocket knife from a lath — & consisted of nine piece: — the head & body carved in one; arms - each two pieces - the joints fitted with a bent hairpin or piece of wire put thro' holes burnt in the wood with a red knitting pin; the legs - each also jointed & the parts put together in the same way. A hole was burnt thro' the centre of the body. Thro' this string was threaded. One end of this thread was secured by a nail, the other held in the hand. This "dancer" was made to dance by the person holding the string, "jigging" a tune & striking the taut thread with is finger in time.Pop guns: - made from alder - the outer sheath had the pith taken out & the edges trimmed. This was about 6 ins. long & 1 1/4 ins. wide the hollow part being about 1/2 inch in diameter. A piece of ash or other wood about 1 inch in diameter & 8 or 9 ins. long was then obtained. about 3 or 4 ins. was  left for a handle & the remaining length was pared so that it just slid up and down freely thro' the sheath. Pellets of chewed paper were used - two at a time & the one nearest the opening was forced out by pressing on the other with the "ram rod".Tops: - were made by whittling down cotton spools. A nail was inserted for a spike.Whistles: - made from ash in summer. Bark slipped carefully off & the inner part fitted with groove & narrow passage — bark then replaced. Dancing Master made by Michael Dunne, (72) Courtnacuddy. Whistles: Tom Regan Davidstown (13) shown by his father, shown by his father - John Regan (R.I.P) died 1927 aged 77.

5044729/5035002/5135218.title: The Potato Crop
5044729/5035002/5135218.text:
(continued from previous page)
in Spring. When spring comes they are drawn in to the barn or haggard where the bad ones and the seed and the eating potatoes are sortedfrom each other. So this part of the countrythe corn is sown before the potatoes and thepotatoes are sown under the manure. But before the sea this is not done because there isno frost. The spade with which the potatoes are dug is bought but long ago they were made in forges. Wooden ploughs were never used in this district. The farmers help one another in sewingthe potatoes. Potatoes were used as starch longago but is not now.



Homemade ToysWhen my father was a little boy hehad very little toys except those he made himself.He used to make whistles from reeds and birch-bark and catapults to throw stones with. He also used to make bows and arrowsfrom seasoned ash sticks and tops were madefrom empty spools.When my mother was a little girls she used to make cloth dolls and doll's houses from
(continues on next page)

5044731/5035042/5135311.title: Toy-Making of Long Ago
5044731/5035042/5135311.text: Long ago the people made a lot of toys when they were children.They made dolls, balls, and baby houses and tops. This is how they made the dolls, they got a handful of hay or straw and put it in a little bag, then they got a little ball of hay and put it in a cloth and sewed it on to the body. They got two pieces of sticks then for legs and put them each in a cloth and sewed the tops of them on to the body.When they were making balls they got a ball of paper and tied it with a cord then they could play hand ball.When they were making baby houses they got a little pile of stones and built the walls then they got a board and put it on the top for the roof then they put a slate on top of it.Then they put two pieces of boards down in the ground for door posts and they got a door out of a piece of board and nailed it on.They made tops out of thread spools and put sticks up in the them and pared the top of it, then it would spin.My Grandmother Mrs. Annie Mc Gowan told me on the 19.11.38.

5044732/5035109/5135415.title: Homemade Toys
5044732/5035109/5135415.text: A lot of toys can be made at home with wood, and tin [?] & nails & wire.Long ago Dancing masters[?] were made in all the houses.Boys made lovey tops out of spools.Now motor cars are made out of wood.Dolls were made out of rags.Boys now make all sorts of toys out of Meccano sets.Aeroplanes out of old tin box.Wooden horses & cloth horses.People used cut out images out of turnips put lighting candles in them & the candles will shine out through the eyes.There are people in Avoca named Misses Wynne. They have a toy making industry in Avoca.  They cut out the toys in cloth & give them out to the [?] girls & children in the district they sew them up & the constant employees fill these shapes with sawdust or other filling.

5044732/5035123/5135431.title: Toys Made Locally
5044732/5035123/5135431.text: Thomas Moore made a lot of lovely  songs such as Meeting of the Waters & The Minstral boy.Thomas Moore was sitting under an oak tree at the Meeting of the Waters in Avoca when he made the song as the thoughts came to him.

5044703/5033180/5136263.title: Homemade Toys
5044703/5033180/5136263.text:
The girls of this district make "Daisy Chains by spliting the stem of the flower near the top, and sliping the flower in and so on until it is big enough to go around your neck. Some make a crown for the head out of "Butter Cups" They pull the stem from the flower and sew the flower along a tread and it makes a lovely crown. Then they play pretending one of them is the queen with the crown of "Butter Cups" on her head. They also stuff an old stocking with saw dust, and sew dust in a piece of cloth for the head, thay sew a little piece of Coloured wool for nose, and a piece of
(continues on next page)

5044718/5034282/5136565.title: Homemade Toys
5044718/5034282/5136565.text:
Boys often follow their mothers about the place looking for old spools to make dancers.First they get a penknife and pare the spool to a point at one end  Then they get a used match and point it on one end.  They put the match through the spool and try it on a flat plate to see if it will run smoothly.  Guns are made from elder branches.  These are called "potguns."  The elder poles were cut and and the path was pushed out of them.  Next paper pellets the size of the hole in the stick was secured in the following manner, small pieces of paper was procured and made round in shape.  Then a "ram-rod" was made thus, a long round piece of stick the size of the hole in the stick was got.  Then the pellet was put in the point of the "gun"  and the rod after it.  Then the rod was hid against a
(continues on next page)

5044747/5036002/5137546.title: Homemade Toys
5044747/5036002/5137546.text:
Home Made ToysTheir was a boy in Tomnafinogue long ago by the name of William Donegan who made cradle "birds". he got wire and wood. He made a wooden roof and he made the side of it from wire and he put a little wooden door on it and he put bird sed in it and he put a long cord from the door in through the window. He would put the cradle bird on the wall in front of the house and when a bird would go in to eat the seed he would pull the cord and the door would shut and he would catch the bird.Children used to make toys long ago. One of the toys they used make was a gun for shooting water. They used to get a straight round stick. They used to put a hole in it for another piece of stick to go through. They used to put a piece of leather on the piece of stick that goes through the hole. Then they put it through the hole and they put it in water
(continues on next page)

5044750/5036251/5137674.title: Homemade Toys
5044750/5036251/5137674.text:
Girls sometimes gather daises and make daisy chains. They make a hole in the stem of the daisy, and they run (and the) another stem of a daisy through it.Sometimes others make rag dolls. They put a piece of old clothes in the centre of a cloth. Then they twist the piece of cloth around and tie it with strings and then appears the neck and head. They sew up both sides with thread. They roll up stuff into arms and legs. They work black and white thread around a little soft for the eyes. They get wool and out it on their heads for hair. Then they have a nice little doll.They had old ways for catching birds. They used to trap birds with nets in the olden days. Other days they need to get a board and put the board up a twig and tie a
(continues on next page)

5044757/5036582/5137765.title: Local Place Names
5044757/5036582/5137765.text:
(continued from previous page)
different places have been mentioned as the site. Mr Kearns' land, Mr Cosgrave's land, and Mr Phillip O'Reilly's land.There is the ruin of an old Church in the Townland of Kilmacoo. It is said to be the oldest ruin in the district. There is a graveyard attached with tombstones in it, but no names or dates can be seen on them, as they have all fallen down on their faces. The place is very much overgrown and nobody around seems to know much about its history, but I have been told by Mr Aaron Burns of Knockenree that he heard that the Church was build by the Druids about the year 640.

5044570/5023232/5138008.title: Homemade Toys
5044570/5023232/5138008.text: There is an old tradition told about home made toys but it is not so common nowadays. Some of the toys that are easily made are cars, guns, tops and many others. The cars are made out of a small wooden box with spools for wheels.

5044752/5036366/5138068.title: Homemade Toys
5044752/5036366/5138068.text: Girls make necklaces of daisies. A hole is made in the stem of the daisy, with a pin and the daisies are strung together. Boys make tops of thread spools. They pare the spool until it is quite even: then they bore a small hole in it and put in a nail. Boys get thin runner and they tie it on the two pieces of sticks: they put stones in it and hit birds with them.They make snares out of thin wire: three pieces of wire are put together: a cord is put at the end of the wire: there is a stake to hold the rabbit. These toys are not gone out of fashion but there were many more made long ago.

5044766/5036998/5138394.title: Homemade Toys
5044766/5036998/5138394.text:
Boats: Get two or three corks and join them together with match sticks. Get two nails to act as a balance for the corks. Put in two match-sticks for masts and put paper on them. Get a tin can and take the bottom out of it. Then flatten it and then bend the ends and hammer them together.Lantern: Get a mangel and scoop it out and put a lighted candle in it and put a piece of glass over the front of it and it will show light. A Top: Get a spool and carve one side in the shape of a top and put a nail in it.Bow and arrow: Get a piece of a sally and tie a piece of cord to both ends. Get another piece of stick and point it.
(continues on next page)

5044572/5023375/5138425.title: Homemade Toys
5044572/5023375/5138425.text: Home Made ToysDaisy ChainWe used to gather a pile of daisies, and put  a nick in each stem and put another daisy through it, in the form of a chain, and we used the chains for necklaces, bracelets, hairbands or belts.PotteryWe used to make pottery out of lumps of yellow clay we found in the garden, we bruised the lumps and some water if it was dry, then we modelled it into cups, saucers, jugs, vases, teapots or even animals, and put them into the over to bake.Toy furnitureWe made furniture for dolls houses out of card-board and covered them with nice cloth. We made chairs, couches, beds and stools.ShoesI used to make shoes out of card-board and sew cloth to them.

5044573/5023413/5138453.title: Homemade Toys
5044573/5023413/5138453.text:
247Home-made ToysChildren always find amusement in making toys. Little girls string flowers into a chain. They are always fond of making dolls. They get odd pieces of cotton and stitch it up in the shape of a doll. Boys make toys out of thread spools. They point one end of it and put a piece of stick through the middle of it. They made cribs for trapping birds. They were made out of sallies. Skittels was another game played. There were five small sticks cut about three inches long. There were three longer and heavier pieces cut about seven or eight inches long. The small ones are numbered and four of them are placed the shape off a square and number five placed in the middle. Then they stand back about four or five yards and throw the three heavy sticks one by one and try to knock down the small ones. There is a game called first and whoever knocks out
(continues on next page)

4921591/4882409/5138627.title: Homemade Toys
4921591/4882409/5138627.text:
Long ago the children of Crookhaven and the surrounding districts made all their own toys. The girls made dolls out of different material as paper, rubber, wood and cloth. They also made necklaces from different wild flowers.The boys made many toys as guns, tops, slings, snares and bird baskets. They made the guns from the branches of the elder tree. Tops were made from old threadspools. Slings were made from a long narrow twig with a cord from one end of the twig to the other this was used for throwing stones. Snares were made for catching rabbits or hares. They were made out of snare wire with a loop at one end. They put theses snares outside the rabbit borrow so when the rabbit stepped on the wire it would choke him. Bird baskets were also made out of twigs to catch birds.All theses toys are made to the present day in
(continues on next page)

5044609/5025490/5139679.title: Homemade Toys
5044609/5025490/5139679.text:
The toys which are usually made at home is a daisy chain and a hurling ball. The way you make a daisy chain is you gather a lot of daisies and cut a hole in the stalk of the daisy and put another daisy into that hole and keep doing that until you have the chain long enough. The way you make a hurling ball is to get a lot of corks and cut them up into small pieces and put them into an old piece of a stocking and get a needle and twine and stitch the ball with the needle and twine. The way you make a doll you get a head of a doll and then get a piece of cloth and make it into a body and sow it on to a head and stuff it with rags and then get two pieces of sticks and make them into arms and two other pieces and make them into feet and then the doll is made.

These are made out of heads of cowslips. First get a bit of thread and them put the heads of the cowslips in a row along the thread and then tie the two ends of the thread together.

5044611/5025688/5140102.title: Homemade Toys
5044611/5025688/5140102.text:
The girls and boys of long ago made their own toys.Dolls were made of wood and rags. Most girls took an interest in dressing dolls. They made dresses, skirts, jumpers, scarfs, and many other kinds of dresses. Sometimes cradles were made, and this was done with a boot box.Crosses were also made, and they were called St Patrick's Crosses.A cross was made from the cardboard and around it were little ornaments worked with coloured papers. There were worn on the shoulders of the children.The boys made slingers, and cribs for catching birds, tops, catapults and various other toys.Slingers were made from a piece of cord and a piece of leather.A stone was placed in the leather, and then swung around in the air and in this way the stone shot through the air.Catapults were made from pieces of rubber and a forked stick.The cribs were made in the shape
(continues on next page)

5044601/5025018/5140651.title: Homemade Toys
5044601/5025018/5140651.text: Making toys makes your hands active and light. I made a necklace of daisies and tied the ends to one another. I made clothes for a doll with old clothes. I made a doll with some straw to play with and covered it with old clothes. I just rolled it the straw up and made a doll with it. I made a "dozey ball" with cowslips. I tied a string to a chair and tied the cowslips on it and tied the two together and I played with it but after a while it broke up in pieces.My Brother Francis can make a catapult and a sling. My Brother Tommy can make a crib for catching birds and I saw it when he finished it. My Father and Mother never made toys when they were small. That is all the toys I made when I was very small.

5044614/5025911/5140698.title: Homemade Toys
5044614/5025911/5140698.text:
Dolls are often made at home by little girls.  They are made out of cloth and their faces made with card board.  Then their eyes, nose, and mouth are drawn with coloured pencil and they look very nearly as good as bought dolls.There are also cradles made at home in the houses and they are made out of boxes such as card board ones.  Children are very fond of making frocks for their dolls also bed clothes for the cradle.Boys often made cribs for catching birds.  They make them out of sticks.  They also make a kind of gun called a cata pult with which they throw stones to kill birds.There is another kind of gun called a "slinger" which you swing around in the air and swing a stone out of it.Boys also make tops out of wood and a nail.  There is another top called a "Teetom Totom" which they
(continues on next page)

One end of it is paired, a piece of a stick is put through the hole for a point. Another kind of top is called a teetum tootum. It is made of a spool. A goose's windpipe: blow into it and it is like a goose roaring.A dodgie-ball: The way to make a dodgie-ball is to get cowslips and hand them on thread and when the thread is covered, it is pulled tight and tied and all the cow-slips are turned into a round ball. Then it is thrown up, and by trying to keep it up, it becomes a game.



Snare: A snare is made of wire called snare wire. The way it is made is to get about six pieces of wire and twist them together and make a little loop in one of the ends and put the other end through the loop making a sliding loop. It is pegged to the ground on a rabbits run.Catapult: A catapult is made out of two pieces of rubber, and a little pieces of leather and a piece of wood called the fork. Huzzer: The boys make a huzzer out of a button and a piece of twine. Get a piece of tea twine and put one end of the twine out of one hole and the other end of the twine out on the other hole. Then tie the two pieces of twine together. They put one finger in one side, and their thumb in the other side, and then wind it in circle with the right hand and hold it the left hand. Then they pull in and cut with one hand, making the button revolve at a great speed which makes a soft buzzing sound.

5044601/5025091/5141075.title: Homemade Toys - A Crib
5044601/5025091/5141075.text:
First you get four elder rods each about a foot or a foot and a half long and then get a string and make a square and tie them at each corner.Then you get two strong cords and two feet long and tie them diagonally from corner.Then you get four more elder rods slightly shorter than the first four and then continue like that till you get near the top.  I then get more short elder rods to fill the hold at the top.Then you get a strong stick and put it under the cords on top of

5044601/5025093/5141081.title: Homemade Toys - A Whistle
5044601/5025093/5141081.text: First you get a sycamore rod and cut round the barkabout 2 1/2'' down stick and you cut a round hole in the bark about 1/2'' down stick.Then you slip off the bark and hten there is a little hole in the stick.You then cut the hole deeper in stick - about 1/4'' down and 1/2'' long.Then you slip the bark on again and blow.  if it does not whistle you take it off again and cut notch deeper and try it again.

5044664/5030136/5141105.title: Homemade Toys
5044664/5030136/5141105.text: I often made little chains from daisies by putting the stems of the daisies in and out through one another. Then I wore it around my neck as an necklace. I also made crosses, I would get a piece of carboard and I would make holes in it the shape of a cross then I would put the stems of the daisies in the holes and it would look as if it was adorned with gems. I often made a belt from the glassy paper that would be around cigarette packets. I would fold the paper a certain way then I would put that paper into another folded paper and so on. When I would have it long enough I would put a buckle in it and it look like ivory. I made a rag doll out of rags and sawdust. I would sew the rags in the shape of a doll then I would put in the sawdust. Then I would make a dress and put it on her and I would put two black dots for her eyes. Then I would put two sticks for her arms and two more for her legs. Then she would be completed.

5044664/5030137/5141109.title: Homemade Toys
5044664/5030137/5141109.text: I often made tops out of a piece of timber and I put a nail for a spear. Then we made a ring and put some top in the ring and pegged at it. I often set snares for hares and rabbits. I would put a stake down in the ground then I would get a piece of a stick and put it under the snare and rise it about three inches off the ground and then put it on the rabbits track  I often made skittles and played them.

5044620/5026630/5141929.title: Local Cures
5044620/5026630/5141929.text:

Girls around here find much amusement making daisy-chains. They remove the stems from the daisies and put a needle and thread through the center of the flowers. These chains may be worn around neck, wrists, or hair.Another kind of chain is made by (pla) putting the stem of one flower through the stem of the next and so on.TopsBoys usually make tops at home. They get a spool and point one end. Then put a bit of stick through the hole of the spool. A whip for flogging the top is made by tieing a piece of string on the end of a stick.In Winter when the snow is on the ground boys make cribs for catching birds. The crib is a kind of basket made of rods and is set standing on its mouth
(continues on next page)

5044661/5029755/5142432.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029755/5142432.text: Some time ago when it snowed the people made bird traps. One end of a briar was put in the ground and then bent back and placed with a basin on top of it so that the basin will be four inches from the ground. A long piece of thread is tied to the briar - Crumbs of bread should be placed under the basin so that the bird would go under it. When the bird would go under the basin the thread is pulled and the basin would fall on the bird and trap her. The boys around St Mullins also made peashooters from a weed that grew along the river bank.

5044661/5029756/5142467.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029756/5142467.text: In this country boys and girls make all sorts of toys for a pastime. The girls make dolls of rags and straw. When making a doll get a wisp of straw and a piece of cloth. Place the straw inside the cloth and sew it up. Then it would look a smart doll.In olden times the children used to make tops, guns, and ships. The tops were made from wood with a spear in the middle to make it go around. The young boys would have great fun spinning them on the tarred roads. The ships were made of paper and wood. When the wind was blowing on the Barrow a very young man of twentyone years of age dived after a little ship and was drowned.

5044661/5029757/5142471.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029757/5142471.text: In summer time many girls pick flowers and make necklaces of daisies, butter cups blue bells and many other wild flowers. In the Summer holidays I often pick wild flowers and make necklaces.Mountain ash is the name of a tree on which red berries grow and you could make a necklace of them.

5044661/5029763/5142489.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029763/5142489.text: Boys make cradles for birds. They get four pieces of laths and make a square of them. They get sallow sticks and lay one upon another a quarter of an inch apart and they keep putting on the sticks until they come to a top where they tie them with wire.To make a snare stick two nails in a board about one foot and a half apart. Put the wire from one nail to another until you have six strands. Then take it off one nail and twist it. Get a piece of a cord about half a foot long and get a peg and tie the cord to it.

5044661/5029774/5142534.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029774/5142534.text: Children some time ago made toys and other things in their spare time. The girls made necklaces and crowns from flowers. First they gather the flowers and join the stems together. They made dolls from cloth.The boys made tops from reels of thread from which the thread was used. They made guns from timber and snares from thin wire and a piece of a stick to trap rabbits. They put a loop on the wire big enough for the rabbit to put its head through and then it pulled and it was choked.Some children still make those toys. Boys make snares to catch rabbits. Girls still make chains from flowers and dolls from cloth and they make other things also.

5044661/5029775/5142548.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029775/5142548.text: Long ago there were very queer ways for making toys. They would make dolls of rags having a white rag for a face and black marks for the nose and mouth. They would make dresses and bibs for them. There was great fun making cats, dogs, birds and all sorts of animals from grease of candles and from dough. Some girls make necklaces from berries which grow on trees.Boys get papers and make boats from them. They put them in a barrel of water and let them sail round. When they are wet they pull them asunder and tear them.

5044661/5029780/5142559.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029780/5142559.text: Girls and boys in their spare time make toys from walnuts and pieces of cloth. A doll is one toy I often made from a handkerchief  I would leave the hankerchief down flat on a table. I would roll up the two long sides until they lay side by side. I would take the farther end of the two rolls and double them over, so that they almost touch the nearer end  Then I would bend the nearer end just folded  The handkerchief is pressed with one hand and with the other the two corners are pulled downwards. These stand for legs. Then I take out the other two corners and pull them out sideways. These are the two arms. I tie these two latter ends over the mass of handkerchief an inch from the end. I have then a hankerchief doll

5044661/5029784/5142610.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029784/5142610.text: Boys have many ways for amusing themselves  In snowy weather when the birds are very cold and hungry boys make cribs for catching them. They make the cribs of sticks arranged in the shape of a house. There is great sport in making pop-guns of bicycle pumps. The top is taken off and a cork is put up in the pump and blown out. It makes a loud report. Boys make snares of light wire  Six strands of this are put together and are twisted. A small loop is put on one end and the other end is put through the loop and made round. A cord and a bit of a stick are tied to the wire and then it is set on a rabbit path and when she runs into it she gets choked

5044661/5029793/5142662.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029793/5142662.text: Last summer I had great sport making toys. I made a very nice little toy house with five windows. I got timber and cut it very thin I drew out a house with my hand.I cut through the timber with a fretsaw and made the windows. When I had this finished I made one door and two little chimneys. When I had finished all I made a little doll. I sewed two pieces of cloth together  I put feathers inside of the cloth. Then I painted a piece of paste-board for her neck and face. When I had finished my mother said she was an unbreakable doll. I played for a long time with the little doll. I made a little chain for her in the little house and she used to sit down on it  When my mother would tell me that I could play, I would play with my doll and house

5044661/5029824/5142864.title: Homemade Toys
5044661/5029824/5142864.text: The girls used to make dolls of potatoes. They used to make the legs and hands of sticks and they put wool on their heads for hair. They made flowers of paper. The boys made pop guns of elder trees. It should be bored through and bullets made of flax would be put in the end. They put the other bullet at the other end. A stick called the ramrod fired them out. They made flutes of an elder tree. When bored through six small holes were made on the side for your fingers and one to blow in. They made a man's head of a turnip. All but the skin would be scooped out and eyes were cut in it. For teeth matches were fixed in the mouth and a candle was lighted inside.

Home-made Toys.To make a doll, get a potato and a stick. Peel the potato and bore two holes for eyes. Fill them with blue and then cut a slit for a mouth. Put on a bit of red lead as a nose. Make a hole at one end of the potato and into this put the stick as body. It ihas no legs or arms. make the hair of sheep's wool and place it in a hole in the head. The you dress the doll. To make a cart. Get boards and nail them together. Then get two polish-lids and use them as wheels. Bore a hold in each lid and put a stick through them. Nail this stick to the other boards leaving a wheel at each side. Nail on two sticks as shafts. To make a spinning top. Get a spool
(continues on next page)

5044643/5028496/5143797.title: Homemade Toys
5044643/5028496/5143797.text:
Home made ToysSkittlesSkittles are made of five pieces of cylinder shaped woods and three pieces of longer wood.The short wood are all numbered 1 to 5.  A ring is then made and no. 5 is placed in the middle, no. 3 and 4 a made to line with no. 5.  Then no. 1 and 4 are made to line with no. 5 also so that they all form a cross.  Each player takes his three pieces of wood and stands back a little distance and throws them at the small pieces.  If he can get any of them out of the ring and they are counted.He is the winner if he can get his count as far as twenty first.Dogs and CatDog and cat is a game made from to pieces of wood, one long and one short.  The short one is round and pointed on one end so as to keep the point a little off the ground.  The first player takes the long stick and tops the pointed end of the short stick and it will fly into the air.  Then he hits it off before it hits the ground and whoever hits it the furthest wins the game.
(continues on next page)

5044643/5028497/5143823.title: Homemade Toys
5044643/5028497/5143823.text:
(continued from previous page)
A PropellerA propeller is made out of a piece tine. The make it, it must be made round on both ends. Then it must be cut in the middle and made narrow. Then twisted so that it will catch the wind and will revolve. Then it must be put on a piece of wire. This is done by putting the wire through it. Then the wire is turned up at the end which is put out through the hole and then the wire is put on a piece of stick. Then it is complete.



At this time of the year all boys make cribs to catch birds. We make them out of hazel sticks in the shape of a basket. Each stick is cut the same length and the four corners tied with binding twine. When we have the crib made we tie a briar out of the two hind corners. There we get a weak stick and set it. We out light sticks on the briar and bread under it.

5044667/5030495/5143888.title: Homemade Toys
5044667/5030495/5143888.text:
Home-made toys are in common use in this district.Girls make dolls: they fill the leg of stocking with straw, rags or sawdust to form the head, they tie a string round the filled stocking about quarter way up from one end & cover this with a white cloth on which they draw eyes, nose & mouth. Then they dress the remaining 3/4 with material of different colors. Girls made dolls cradles & dolls proms also. They make them out of wooden boxes putting pieces of ply wood bent, underneath the cradles to form the rockers; & attaching lids of polish boxes to the proms to form the wheels.In Spring & Summer the girls adorn themselves with fuschia earrings, red berries necklaces, & chains of hair bands made by stringing daisies or violets or primroses together. They also visit marshy land where they weave dainty baskets from rushes.The boys are expert in making Cribs to entrap birds, snares to catch rabbits, slings, kites, bows & arrows, tops from spools, windmills & lanterns. To make a lantern, they scoop out the inside of a turnip from one side, put a lighting
(continues on next page)

5044663/5029983/5143999.title: Local Cures
5044663/5029983/5143999.text:
(continued from previous page)
looking for it.  When it was found you should wash your hands in it.  Another way to cure warts was to get a snail in a box and make the sign of the cross on the warts and hang it on a hawthorn tree.When the people had a sty on their eye they got the thorn of a goosberry and made the sign of the cross with the thorn and then point the thorn at it.  They cured the sting of a nettle with a dockroot.Boils were cured with sugar and soap. First they pounded the sugar into dust and then mixed the sugar and soap together and put it on the boil. Sore eyes were cured with cold tea. The tea was spilled into a basin and then the person who had the sore eyes washed them in the tea.



The children used to make several toys of their own long ago such as guns, tops, dolls and wheelbarrows.  They made guns from elder sticks.  The inside of the stick was cut out and
(continues on next page)

5044649/5028889/5144482.title: Homemade Toys
5044649/5028889/5144482.text:
Guns were made by young boys in olden days because their parents could not afford to buy the shop manufactured toys because they were too expensive. My Daddy said he made guns when he was a boy.They were made with two sticks, one elder and one ash, tacks, leather and string. A hole was scooped, in the elder one, with a long bladed penknife, in the form of a barrel, for the gun. The bark was skinned off one ask stick so as to make it pass smoothly through the hollow elder stick. A bent stick was tacked on to the ask stick as a place to tie on the leather strap which had a hole in it for the string. Two tacks were hammered into the elder stick so as to fasten the leather
(continues on next page)

5044683/5031683/5145160.title: Homemade Toys
5044683/5031683/5145160.text: The boys and girls around this district make many toys. The girls do not make many toys. Each boy has his own favourite toy to make. Some boys make snares. These snares are used for catching rabbits. Snares are made quite easily with a piece of strong stick and a strong piece of wire.Another toy trap is a cradle-bird which is used for trapping birds. It is made from sally rods and is shaped like a cage.The most dangeous of all is the catapult which is also made of a strong piece of stick and a piece of long rubber.

5044683/5031684/5145162.title: Homemade Toys that I Make
5044683/5031684/5145162.text:
Around my district many home-made toys are often to be seen with the children. Those toys are well made and can be made easily.'Tis often that I make a top or a kite.During the months of spring home-made tops are in full swing as in every street of the town children "flog" their home-made tops up and down. The top is made from real hard wood well shaped, so as to balance it and a long thin spike driven through the centre of the wood.The kite is another home-made toy to be seen here. It is made from two strong thin sticks, a piece of twine and a piece of strong paper. The sticks are put down on each other, making a cross and are tied in the centre. Then the paper is procured and is pasted to the sticks and is doubled round the sticks so as to make it the stonger. The twine is next
(continues on next page)

5044610/5025663/5145232.title: Homemade Toys
5044610/5025663/5145232.text: Every boy and girl finds sport and pleasure in making different kinds of toys. The girls make rag dolls, paper belts, and necklaces with different kinds of flowers.They gather daisies and with them they make daisy chains. The boys spend most of their time, making a number of different toys. They used to make kites, aeroplanes, toy guns, boats, tops and all sorts of small toys.There are very few of these made at present as they are all bought made. They are sent from other countries to Ireland. They also make bird cages and snares. The snares are used for catching hares and rabbits and they are still used for the same purpose.

5044691/5032494/5145998.title: Bird-Lore
5044691/5032494/5145998.text:
(continued from previous page)
The bird lies upon the eggs for three weeks to hatch them



Every girl makes necklaces out of flowers and dolls out of paste board. Boys make yeo-yeos out of paper and rags. They also make birds cages out of wood and wire. Snairs are made for catching hares and rabbits and young foxes. They make fishingrods for catching fish.



The luckiest day to get married is on Wendesday. The most unlucky day to get married is saturday. Men start to work on a Monday. The people sow the potatoes before the 17th of March. All the crops are up in May. The cabbage and carrots and parsnips are left until later Tuesday and Friday are for curing jaundice and evils.



Travelling people still call to our home. People used to go about many years ago. Some of them are poor. They sell cans, tabels, artificial flowers, baskets, necklaces, cups, saucers and many other
(continues on next page)

5044655/5029320/5146151.title: Homemade Toys
5044655/5029320/5146151.text: Every boy and girl makes toys for himself. Girls always make daisy chains and cowslipchains and they dress up a girl for a May Queen.Boys make toys to amuse themselves. They make cribs to catch birds, and they make snares to catch rabbits. they make queer old things out of turnips to frighten people on November's Night. They cut the middle out of the turnip and put a candle in-side it, and they put two eyes in with a piece of red paper in one and a piece of blue paper in the other. They put it up in the ditch to frighten people.

5044700/5032966/5146227.title: Homemade Toys
5044700/5032966/5146227.text:
Long ago boys made homemade toys.  They made tops.  First they got the wood from a crab tree or some hard wood like that.  They then made it round and sharpened one end.  They went to a blacksmith's forge and got him to put the spinner in it.  All the boys would make one.  They also made a little top from a thread spool.  They sharpened one end.  A stick was then got and fitted into the hole of the spool.  They spun this with their fingers.  This top was called a teetotum.They made whistles from sycamore or sally branches, or some wood which would peel easy.  They loosened the skin on the stick.  They then cut a little notch in it.  They then split the stick down to the
(continues on next page)

5044694/5032644/5146694.title: Local Toy-Making
5044694/5032644/5146694.text: There are people in Ireland to-day who give their time to some kind of toy making. It is practiced in the little district of ours. All sorts of toys are made, namely, tops, balls, and even, animals, bicycles, and motor cars. These are also to be had in shops also, but are dear to buy. But of course the ones you would get in the shops would be far stronger, and would be more endurable. The favourite toy made is a foot-ball. Four or five men get together, and they subscribe a certain sum of money each, until they have a sufficient sum to buy the leather. Then they sew the leather together, and make the ball. This is a very profitable pastime. The next one is top-making. It is the big children who use these because the small children would not be able to use them. Top spinning is a very common practice in this locality.

5044680/5031453/5146890.title: Homemade Toys
5044680/5031453/5146890.text:
Long ago, children used to make their own toys. A very popular pastime among the girls is the making of chains from daisies. The stem is cut off, and then a pointer is run through the flower. Then the flower is put on a piece of thread or twine. Among the boys a very pleasant pastime was the making of wheelbarrows. A box was got and two pieces of sticks formed the legs.



In years gone by cribs were a great amusements for young boys during the winter time in frost and snow. The frames were made of elder sticks about eighteen inches long, and twine tied from corner to corner. Sticks were built up inside this twine until it was brought about one inch wide at the top. Then a stick was put in at the top, and twisted that tightened it together. Then there was a briar put underneath the

bottom of the crib from one corner to the other. The crib was cocked on one end, and a forkstick put against it, and a twig between the forkstick connected with the briar in the bottom. Food was left inside the crib. When the bird hopped on the briar the twig came out, and the crib fell down, and the bird was caught in the crib them.



Among the boys a very pleasant pastime was the making of a wheelbarrow. A box was got and two piecces of sticks formed the props. Then a wooden wheel was made and fixed to the box. Nowadays there is no such thing as making our own toys.



Girls gather daisies and break off the stems. They make little holes in the heads of the daisies with a needle or a pin and string them
(continues on next page)

(continued from previous page)
on a piece of thin cord or thread. The first two daisies are place facing each other an the next two are placed the opposite way and so on.



Some children make a hobby of toy-making. I have often seen boys getting a large round turnip and drawing out a man's head and face on it. Then with a penknife and a large spoon the inside of the turnip is cut and scooped away until only the skin remains. Then with paint and a piece of black burnt stick the mouth, eyes and nose are outlined.

5044680/5031456/5146903.title: Homemade Toys
5044680/5031456/5146903.text:
It was a custom, long ago to make guns. An elder branch was got, and the white pith from the inside was taken out. A long straight stick was then got and pushed throught the elder stick. A stone was put in the elder stick, and the rod was pushed in quickly, and the stone would go a far distance. Another game was to scoop the inside of a turnip, then cut "eyes", "nose" and "mouth" on the outside. A lighting candle would then be put inside, and the shell of turnip with the lighting cande place on a gate post at night.

5044687/5032138/5147224.title: Local Toy-Making
5044687/5032138/5147224.text: There are not many toys now made by boys in this district.  Boys sometimes make "men" out of a turnip.  At first they get a turnip and cut the middle out of it.  Then they cut the shape of a man out of it.They also make tops.  At first they get a spool and they pare it down until there is a point on it.  Then they put a nail out through it and it does as a top.Girls make dolls from rags, sewn together and filled with bran or sawdust.

5044687/5032209/5147567.title: Homemade Toys
5044687/5032209/5147567.text: How to make a kite is to get three pieces of wood and nail them together and make it like a triangle and cover it with paper put a tial on it and a long twine tight.  To make a catopult is to get a forked piece of wood and get two pieces rubber and a piece of leather and then tie them all together.  To mak a hoop, get a piece of paling wire and get it welded

4921594/4882854/5147809.title: Homemade Toys
4921594/4882854/5147809.text:
Girls and boy samuse themselves with the making of toys. Girls make chains out of daisies. They first pick the daisies. They get a needle and thread about a yard long and put it through the centre of the daisy until they have the thread full and then they knot the two ends together and they have their chain made.Some of them make dolls, they get a piece of paper and paint the features of a child on it. Then they get a piece of timber to form the head. They glue on the hair and features to this. They then get a fancy piece of cloth and make a dress for the dollBoys make top dancers out of spools. They cut the spool in the centre and get a piece of stick to fit the hole in the centre of the spool. They draw one end of it to a point and leave a piece of stick out at the other end so as to spin it. They also make pop guns out of elder branches. They first cut the piece of elder without any knot or branch they hallow out the centre and they have a nice piece of stick for a ram rod. Their bullets were piece of paper chewed in their mouth they put the first bullet in and hen they fill the gun of air with their mouth having the second bullet at the same time in their mouth and they press it for wards as to keep in the air. They then take their rod and hold it against one of the bullets and strike it with the palm of their hand. Then it would explode and one bullet would fire
(continues on next page)

5044688/5032380/5147883.title: Homemade Toys
5044688/5032380/5147883.text:
The children made a great many toys at home long ago such as dolls, rush hats, daisy chains. Rag dolls are made of cloth. First they make a small bag and put padding inside and cloth over it. They make a small bag and fill it for a head. They sew on beads for eyes in them, and fasten on two pieces of sticks to them for legs and two other pieces for the arms.         When my father was at school both the boys and girls used to play a game called "Cat and dog" They got a bit of stick about a foot long and almost an inch thick. This was called the dog. They also got a bit of stick not quite so thick about five or six inches long. They pared this to a fine point each end. This was called the cat.        Some children make rush hats, and kites, also daisy chains. First they gather rushes and twist them all around. They make the kites in the
(continues on next page)

5044645/5028630/5148003.title: Homemade Toys
5044645/5028630/5148003.text: There are a great many toys made in this district namely: rag dolls, trailers, daisy chains, snares for catching rabbits, and snares for catching birds.A rag doll can be made from straw and rags. The commonest are made from straw. First you get half a yard of white cloth. Then cut out the body and legs of the doll. Sow up the sides of the doll. Then get straw and stick it down into the doll. Then cut out the head and stuff it with straw also. Then get a pencil and mark the eyes nose and mouth of the doll. Then sow on the head to the body. Country children delight in making rag dolls.

5044645/5028631/5148006.title: Homemade Toys
5044645/5028631/5148006.text: To make a daisy chain you must first pick a bunch of daisies. The make a hole in the stem of a daisy with the nail of your thumb. Then put the stem of another daisy in through the hole of the first daisy and so on till it is big enough to go round your neck.

5044645/5028632/5148014.title: Homemade Toys - A Pop Gun
5044645/5028632/5148014.text: Many boys can make a pop-gun from an elder stick. First they cut a fairly thick elder stick and bore a hole down the centre of it. The hole must be straight and the same breadth at both ends or else the bullet will not pass through. The bullet can be made from a turnip or from paper. A bullet is placed at each end. Then the get a stick and push one of the bullets down the hole. This causes pressure of air and the air blows out the other bullet.

5044645/5028633/5148016.title: How to Make a Snare
5044645/5028633/5148016.text: Many boys amuse themselves by snaring rabbits and hares during the winter. To make a snare you must first buy a roll of snare wire. This wire is got in hardware shops only. Wind five or six strings of wire together. If you wind them too tight the snare might break and let loose your rabbit or hare. The setting of the snare is most important. You tie the snare to a small piece of a stick and stick the stick in the ground. They stick another small piece of stick in the ground prop the snare on it. If a rabbit passes the pass during the night it is your fault if he is not caught for if the snare is set right he is sure to be caught.

4921598/4883236/5148384.title: Folk Toys
4921598/4883236/5148384.text:
Long ago the people used make lovely toys. They used make very pretty hats out of rushes and called them rushawns.   They used make daisy-chains. They used take two daisies at the time, one in each hand, and they used put the stem of one daisy into the flower of the other one. They used continue that until the chain would be the desired length.   They used make penknives out of the tops of old turf shovels and they put fir handles on them.    For whistles they used get a piece of twig soft in the centre such as ash. They used scoop out the soft marrow put a hole in one side and then it was made.   They used make rag dolls, they used stuff them with wood shaving and they used make the eyes with black beads. They used shape the nose and the mouth with thread.   They used trace three rows of boiled peeled twigs together which
(continues on next page)
