4921598/4883237/5148385.title: Folk Toys
4921598/4883237/5148385.text:
(continued from previous page)
formed a kind of a basket, they used this for making butter.



Toy boats were made of a block of wood and they were shaped out with a pen knife, and fitted with a mast, rudder, keel, and sail.   Pop gun. They used cut a straight bit of ash twig six inches or so. Cut the bark round the twig about mid ways. Beat the bark with the flat of the knife handle, along one half the twig until the bark will loosen. The bark can then be slipped off, and it will make the barrel of the gun. The bare half of the stick will make the plunger, and the other half will act as the handle.   Rattling box. A very pretty rattling box was made of woven rushes.

5044603/5025234/5148554.title: Homemade Toys
5044603/5025234/5148554.text:
Richard Stone is a great toy maker. He can make little cars. He gets the big wheels in a clock. He pares a stick and makes it flat. Then he gets a board and nails it on to the pared stick. He then puts a wheel on each side of the stick. Then he bores a hole on the outside of the stick. He puts a piece of tin in the hole to keep the wheels from falling out. Then he nails two low boards on it for the side-boards. The he nails thin boards on each side for the shafts.



Long ago the people made home-made toys. They made guns out of the elder tree. They shaped the gun first. They made these guns for the children. They made tops with spools. They cut one side of the spool. They got a piece of metal and put it in the hole in the spool. They put a point on the metal. They made horses with card-board. They cut out the horse. Then they got a wooden board and put the horse's feet on the board. They put wheels on the board then. They made boatswith paper. They made a fold with the paper. Then they

5044709/5033413/5148923.title: Homemade Toys
5044709/5033413/5148923.text:
Girls still make daisychains.  They make also caps and teacosies out of plaited rushes.  They do not make rag dolls like long ago.  Boys sometimes made toys out of thread spools; they use to have a stick that would fit down through the hole in the spool, the stick had a very sharp point on it, thus it was made into a topBoys also amused themselves with elder canes.  They used to put a red poker up through the cane.  the smoke would come gushing out.  Finally when the poker reached its destination it shot like a bullet which gave such a game the name of gun pastime.Snares are still made locally to catch rabbits and hares.  There was a simple woman who lived in the Red Bog named Mrs Holmes.  She use to set snares in fairy rings, hoping to find a fairy caught in one, but she never succeeded.When making dolls the girls drew the head and body together by means of a string put through the neck.  The eyes and nose were made of of blackthread sown into the head before it was stuffed.  The head had
(continues on next page)

4921599/4883425/5149268.title: Homemade Toys
4921599/4883425/5149268.text:
Flowers:-The old habit of stringing daisies, primroses, and butter-cups still remain in this locality. It was a great amusement in former days for little girls to make "miunci" and"[?]" but this habit is now dying out.Guns from elder branches:-A great pastime for boys about sixty years ago was the making of guns from elder branches. Their manufacture was simple. An elder branch was first cut the required length and ask iron was driven through the branch to expect the bait. Then the hole was stuffed with sugar papers which were at first damped and a stick was pushed in then, then another sugar paper was put in, and a stick the thickness of the hole was pushed in half-ways. At the other end the finger was placed, and when let go, the paper made a loud charge. The paper was used instead of powder.Bird Baskets:-These baskets were made out of spars of "[?]" having four sides and coming to a point
(continues on next page)

Snares are now commonly made all over this district for the purpose of catching rabbits. The wire is at first purchased and also some strong cord. The wire is then cut into a number of equal length strands. This number varies according to the strength of the wire. The strands are then twisted while a loop which forms an eye is at each end. A strong stick called a peg varying from six inches to a foot in length is then got. This is paned and a notch is put around it about an inch from the top. Around this notch the cord is fastened while it is also fastened to one eye of the snare. Another little thin stick called a standing sick

4798754/4795777/5149330.title: Homemade Toys
4798754/4795777/5149330.text: A great many people long ago made their own toys because they were too poor to buy them, such as dolls, patguns, catapults, model-turnips, whistles, snares, toy-cars, bird-baskets, rattle-boxes, daisy-chains and necklaces.   Dolls were made of rags stuffed with corn, Patguns were made with elder-stick. Catapults, were made with rubber. Whistles were made with horse-chestnuts. Snares were made of wire. Bird-baskets were made with sticks traced in a proper position. Rattle-boxes were made with rushes. Toy-cars were made of little lats nailed together. Daisy-chains were made with daisies joined together. Necklaces were made of indian corn painted different colours.   A turnip could be shaped into the head of a man putting a red paper inside the face, and a candle lighting which makes him look like a ghost.

4921609/4884749/5149444.title: Homemade Toys
4921609/4884749/5149444.text: Home-Made Toys.Long ago boys used to make pop guns out of elder branches. They used to cut a pieces of elder about eight inches long and take out the soft portion of the elder. The inside of the barrel was then about a half-inch in diameter. They used to cut a rod the length of the barrel of the gun and pare it until it would fit into the barrel of the gun, and leave a head on it about an inch long. They used to roll up a piece of paper and make it very hard and press it into the barrel of the gun with a rod. They would blow some wind into the barrel and put in a second bullet. The first bullet would be very near the mouth of the barrel and the other about an inch and a half from the back of the barrel. They would then strike the head of the rod with their hand and it would fire the bullet about five or six yards and make a loud sound.Cornelius Barry,Rathravane,Ballydehob,Skibbereen.Obtained from father.Patk. Barry 55 yrs.

4921609/4884750/5149450.title: Homemade Toys
4921609/4884750/5149450.text: Home-Made ToysThe way to make a sling is, first to get a piece of leather about three inches in length and an inch and a half in width. Next get two pieces of twine of equal lengths and attach them to the leather. The sling is now complete. Then get a stone and put it into the leather and take hold of the two strings and twist the sling quickly around and when it is in force let one string go and the stone will go a great distance.James HellenRathravane,Ballydehob,Skibbereen.Obtained from father.Cor. Heller 49 yrs.

4921609/4884751/5149452.title: Homemade Toys
4921609/4884751/5149452.text: Boys around here used to make catapults for killing birds. A catapult is a forked stick with an elastic banc for throwing stones.    Girls string daisies together into a chain, and they trace three rushes together to make a belt. They also make rush hats and decorate them with wild flowers, and they make belts with toffee-papers and cigarette papers. When binding corm both boys and girls make whistles out of cornblades, and at Christmas time they make necklaces out of holly berries. They also make necklaces out of sgeachóirí (sgeachóirí are red wild berries that come on the wild rose.)

4921609/4884752/5149456.title: Homemade Toys
4921609/4884752/5149456.text: Long ago girls used to make hats out of rushes. When they had the rushes plucked they used to leave them quail. They used then trace them into plaits and then sew all the plaits together in the form of a hat. Mats were made out of straw and suidhsteens were also made out of straw.Girls at the present day string flowers together, and make necklaces and belts out of them. Belts are made out of toffee papers and also out of cigarette papers.

4921605/4884202/5149666.title: Homemade Toys
4921605/4884202/5149666.text:
Snares were made very plentifully long ago, but are not so familiar now. They were made with wire, and they were used for catching hares and rabbits.



Pop guns were very popular toys long ago. A piece of elder used to be got about one foot and a half long, and a hole used to be burned through it, and another piece used to be got about one foot three ins, long and it used to be used as a ramming rod through the big piece. Two pieces of paper used then be got and made hard with spits and rolling. When the rod is shoved out and the outer piece will fly out.
(continues on next page)

4921605/4884204/5149672.title: Toy-Making
4921605/4884204/5149672.text:
Snares are still made in my district. They are made to catch rabbits and hares. They are made out of copper wire. Six strands of wire about one foot six inches long are wound round each other leaving an eye in the top of the wire for the other end to go through.Bird baskets were made in my district also, but they are not made now.Slings were made in my district but they are not made now.



Every girl and many boys go out in a field picking daisies, and they make chains of them. Rabbit-catching is carried on here now, but hare catching is not carried on here. Snares are used more for catching rabbits around here.
(continues on next page)

4921605/4884205/5149682.text:
(continued from previous page)
The snares are not used for catching hares because people would have to go far away for them.



Snares for catching rabbits are still being made in this district. Five or six strands of copper wire, about a foot and a half in length, are twisted together, and an eyelet is fastened in one end of the wire, and the other end is put through the eyelet, and thus the snare is made.Slings and catapults were used very much formerly, but are now discontinued.They used to be made by boys, with a gabhlóg, and rubber, and leather. Each end of the rubber is attached to the gabhlóg, and the leather is attached
(continues on next page)

4921605/4884206/5149683.title: Homemade Toys
4921605/4884206/5149683.text:
(continued from previous page)
to the middle of the rubber, and the stone is put into the leather, and the stone will go according to the strength of the rubber, and thus the catapult is made.A sling is made with leather and two pieces of string.Each piece of string is attached to the leather, and a stone is put into the leather, and the sling is twisted, and one of the strings is left go, and the stone goes out of the sling.



Every boy and many girls find a pleasure in making toys. Girls string daisies together to make a chain. Boys make snares for catching hares and rabbits by getting wire and twisting it around each other. They then get a strip of iron to hold it in the ground.

4921605/4884207/5149685.title: Homemade Toys
4921605/4884207/5149685.text:
Some girls make strings of flowers for necklaces, and boys make snares to catch rabbits and hares. Some boys trap wild birds. They trap wild ducks, and they make bird baskets to catch blackbirds, or thrushes, and other wild birds.



Boys make snares for catching rabbits and hares and bird baskets for trapping birds. Girls used to make necklaces out of flowers and sceachóirí. They also make dolls by stringing flowers together. Catapults were made with a gabhlóg and rubber and leather.

Some girls make strings of flowers for necklaces, and boys make snares to catch rabbits and hares. Some boys trap wild birds. They trap wild ducks, and they make bird baskets to catch blackbirds, or thrushes, and other wild birds.



Boys make snares for catching rabbits and hares and bird baskets for trapping birds. Girls used to make necklaces out of flowers and sceachóirí. They also make dolls by stringing flowers together. Catapults were made with a gabhlóg and rubber and leather.

Long ago the people used to make guns in the following way:- A hole is made in the middle of a branch of an elder tree, and got an other stick, and made a handle in the stick, and made the stick fit right in the gun. It would fire stones by shoving the stick in the hole of the branch.Many boys make snares for catching hares and rabbits. They also make bird-baskets for catching birds in the Winter. The following contrivances were used by boys long ago for catching hairs, rabbits and birds-: the bird basket, the "leac ar tinneal", the snare and the pop-gun."Bird Basket"The first that was done when making this contrivance was to get four thin sticks about six inches long and one inch wide.  These were nailed or tied firmly together in the form of a square.  Then four other sticks were obtained and they were nailed or tied to the corners of the square one at each corner. They are sloping inwards towards each other and come to meet at a point over the

Long ago the people had no guns to kill the birds etc. They used to trap them. The following is an account of how to make a bird basket and to set it so as to trap birds : - You must first make a square frame out of four thin boards about a foot long and an inch wide. From the four corners eight briars must meet on top, two from each corner and must be tied firmly with cord. Then the sides must be filled in with wicker work. The cage is made then.The next thing is to set it. To one side of the frame a twig is fixed in a semi-circular position in the inside. This twig must be fixed in such a way that when the cage is let down it will remain about three inches off the ground. The cage is put on the ground and raised on one side leaving the side where the twig is, on the ground. It is kept in this position by a

They make them out of horse-chestnuts by clearing out the middle, and out of a corn stalk before it is threshed. By putting a green blade of grass between the hands and blowing through it, a sound like a cock's crow is made. People also make hats out of rushes. People some-

This is often used for frightening people at night.Pop-guns are made out of elder by clearing out the pitch and then getting another stick for a ram rod. The two ends of the gun are plugged with paper. The ram rod is forced through one end, and the force of the compressed air causes the bullet to shoot through the other end of the gun maing a loud report.

4921636/4886999/5153318.text:
Years ago when they were no toys the people used make toys of their own. The kite was the chief toy. Some of the old people were very skilled in making them. Another homemade toy was the pop gun. It used be made chiefly of elder by driving the soft middle out of it and then it used act much like a water-gun.Every young lad used have his own bowl for bowling. That time they used make it out of the soles of old [?] shoes.



In olden times the children had not any toys but those they made at home. At Christmas when they killed a goose they used make a "Leap-Jack" from the breast bone. They tied a piece of string to each end of the bone and joined them together. Then they got a short little twig and put it in the centre of the string and twisted it around until it

4921649/4887732/5153349.title: Homemade Toys
4921649/4887732/5153349.text: Most children make a great many toys.  I often made a sling out of rubber and a stick tied together.Many boys often make a shotgun.  It is is made of an old carbine box.  Make a hole in the box and place it flat on the floor.  After this light a match and put it against the hole of the box. Then the cover will burst out and will make a big shot.Other boys make a whistle of two cartridges.  Put on into the other.  Then put a hole in the cartridges and you will have a good whistle.I often made a ball out of horse's hair.  Boys always on a frosty night fill a bottle of water and put the cork in it.  If the cork would not fly out, the bottle would be burst in the morning.

4921649/4887733/5153351.title: Homemade Toys
4921649/4887733/5153351.text:
Nearly every person could make some kind of an home-made toy.Sometimes a necklace of daisy's. They get a needle and thread and gather the heads of daisies and sew them all together, and then the necklace is made. People often make a home-made ball for children, by getting many pieces of wool and joining them, and leaving them very loose. Sometimes people make a rag doll, by cutting a piece of cloth the shape of a doll, and sewing it except at one end. From this end it is filled with sawdust and then a face is made by painting eyes a nose a mouth and ears on it.People sometimes knit a teddy bear. A person should knit a piece the shape of a teddy bear, fill it with sawdust, and put a bead for each eye and some red wool for the mouth.
(continues on next page)

4921649/4887738/5153356.title: Homemade Toys
4921649/4887738/5153356.text:
Many people delight in making toys during their leisure time.There are many different kinds of toys made from wool, wood and many other things.An old lady showed me how to make a doll out of a clothes peg.  This is the way to make it.  Paint the features on the peg, the parts that hold the clothes are the legs and then dress the doll as desired.There is another way of making a doll.Cut a piece for body and head together, sew both together and stuff with wool or straw.  Then cut pieces for hands and legs, stuff them and sew them on to the body.Engines are made from circular pieces of wood, such as parts of old blind, rollers, etc, and boxes.You should take care to make
(continues on next page)

4921618/4885416/5153473.title: Homemade Toys
4921618/4885416/5153473.text: Home Made ToysI often heard how to make whistles.  First you would get a piece of an elm sapling and keep hitting it with an iron until the bark would loosen, then you would take it off and cut a v shape in the stick, then put on the bark again and blow air into it and it would whistle.  People in our district make those whistles to this day.I often made a chestnut whistle, it is easy to make one.  First you would get a chestnut and put a hole in it and scrape out all the inside and then blow through the hole.  I often made a whistle out of the end of a blade of rye.  I put a slit in it with a knife and blew into it and it would whistle, it is called a "jócawn".Ina DeanePookeenDrimoleagueCo. Cork

4921618/4885478/5153818.title: Homemade Toys
4921618/4885478/5153818.text:
Mother told me they had an old servant long ago who taught them the following game:-One person would hold a splinter of fir or some such thing, with a spail on the end of it; she would then hand it to another person sitting  at the fire with her, and say:-"Seo mo firín duit"Number two would take the splinter and ask:-"Cad is fiú do firín?Number One would take it again   and say"Firín beo, firín marbhDá bhfaghaidh mo firín beó básIdir   do dá láimhBíodh an trom, trom ort"They would keep on saying this until the spark would die and whoever would have it when it would quench should pay a forfeit.Mother said the servant gave them the following translation of the words:-1 - "Here's me little man for you2 - What is he worth?1 - He's worth  this, and he's worth thatAnd if he dies between your two hands,Let all the load be on you."
(continues on next page)

5162177/5161202/5162511.title: Toys and Games - Jack Stones
5162177/5161202/5162511.text:
To play "Jack stones" five stones are needed. The five are thrown up in the air at once.  three must be caught coming down otherwise the game must be started again. One was then thrown up in the air.  One was picked up off the ground. This was repeated and so the five were in the hand. The stones are then placed on the back of the hand. They are thrown up and caught coming down. A stone was then placed between each finger and one was placed on the back of the hand. The one that is one the back of the hand is thrown up. The four on the ground are picked up and the one coming down is caught. This is done three times.



A piece of "boor tree" is taken and the heart is burned out of it with a red hot iron.  One end is plugged with a piece of cork. A ram-rod the fit of the hole is taken and pushed down the open side and so the plug will go off.

5162177/5161203/5162519.title: Toys and Games - The Scotch Hop
5162177/5161203/5162519.text:
Starting point:  Diagramthis diagram was drawn on the road with chalk. A ball was thrown from "starting point" into number one without stepping on a line. A person hops in on the one foot and kicks the ball back to starting point with the foot that is on the ground. The ball is thrown into number two and taken out again. This is continued until the ball arrives in "King's cap".  if the ball stops on a line the game must be started again.



Tops were often made from used spools.  One end of the spool was pared almost to a point.  Then a short piece of rod was taken to fit the hole in the spool and the end of the stick was also pared to a point. The pointed part was put to the ground and spun in this way.

5162177/5161204/5162523.title: Toys and Games - A Buzz
5162177/5161204/5162523.text:
A circular piece of tin was got and a row of nicks put in it like the teeth of a saw.  Two holes are made near the centre of it.  A long piece of string was put through the holes and a nut was put on one end.  When that is done the string is pulled till there is an equal amount of string on each side. The string is twisted with the right hand then it is pulled out with the two hands. This makes a buzzing noise.



A catapult was made with a piece of rubber and a forked stick. A stone was put in it and the rubber was pulled and the stone went off.  The stone would go as far as it would be thrown.

5162158/5160018/5163778.title: Homemade Toys
5162158/5160018/5163778.text:
All children like to make toys at home. The boys make spinning tops. They get a spool and they have one end of it to a point. They get a bit of stick and put into the hole in the spool. They put into the hole in the spool. They put a point on the end of the stick and the top spins on it.The boys make guns out of a piece of boretree. They push the inside which is soft out of the piece leaving a hole in the centre . They get a plug of paper or a pea which represents the shot and put it into it. They get another piece of stick thinner than the first, with this they crush the plug out and it goes off with a bang.Some people make snares for rabbits. They (plat) fine wire and make an eye on one end of the wire. They put the other end through the eye and set it on a rabbit's pad securing it with a rod stuck in the ground. The rabbit will run into it and it will hold it fast. Girls make daisy chains in the Summer time. They gather a pile of daises. They put a hole in the stalk of each and then they...

4921922/4900482/5164732.text:
The time for the daisies is now approaching. They are generally to be seen about the end of February or

A man commonly known as brookstown often visits this district of Mogeely. He is called brookstown because he was born in brookstown, Co. Cork.  He comes of very respectable people and is very well educated.  He addresses every house wife as Auntie.  He was wild and left his own home.

4921584/4882076/5166009.title: Local Homemade Toys
4921584/4882076/5166009.text:
Children of every age in every country home used toys with which to amuse themselves. Many of these toys are made by the children themselves on the instructions of their elders who, in their own childhood were taught the art of toy making.Some of the toys made in this district are - the Bird Basket which is a sort of basket or cage built with sticks held in place with twine and used for trapping birds when frost is on the ground. Snares for rabbits are cleverly formed from special snare wire and are cunningly set near a burrow or rabbit track so as to catch the rabbit unawares.A very popular toy with [a struck through] boys is the Catapult. For this are required a stick in the shape of a gabhlóg, two strips of rubber, a piece of old leather, and twine. This is used for slinging small stones at birds.Whistles of various kinds are made from twigs of the ash and sycamore tree. To make these whistles the bark is carefully removed from the stick, a slight
(continues on next page)

4921738/4901914/5166388.title: Local Marriage Customs
4921738/4901914/5166388.text:
June 28th 1938Local marriage customsIn the Gerdeen district marriages generally take place during Shrove. The month of May is thought unlucky for marriage. Matches are made in this locality and money is given as a fortune, after much bargaining. After sixty years ago marriages took place in the houses, "Straw boys" visitied the houses during the wedding feasts, and departed after being well treated.



Home made toysMy grandmother gave me an account of the home-made todays of long ago. Boys made toys from thread spools and pieces of wood. The made traps or "cribs" for catching birds. Girls played "gobs" with small round stones, and made chains of
(continues on next page)

4921755/4903735/5166477.title: Care of Our Farm Animals
4921755/4903735/5166477.text:
(continued from previous page)
such as "Hurrais""Hurrais" for pigs "Juk""Juk" for hens. When people set eggs for hatching it is said that the eggs should not be washed. There is no mark put on hatching eggs in my district.



A Catapult sling, bow and arrow and top are the principal toys made at home. The Catapult is made by getting a stick in the form of the letter Y and tying a rubber to the tops of the sticks. Then a piece of leather is got and a hole is made in each side and the rubber is put in the holes and tied. A stone is put into the leather and the rubber is pulled and the stone goes. A sling is made by getting a piece of leather and making two holes in it and a cord is put into it. Then a stone is put into it and the sling is swung round in a circle and one cord is let go, and the stone goes. To make a bow and arrow a cord is tied to each end of a stick and another stick pressed against the cord and let go. Birds are trapped by trying a cord to a box under which food is put. When the bird goes under the box the cord is pulled, and the box falls down and the bird is caught.

4811670/4810962/5167516.title: Homemade Toys
4811670/4810962/5167516.text: In former times the people made toys at home but this old custom is dying out of late. The majority of toys are bought in shops. One of the principal home made toys was "cradle birds" now gone out of date.First of all the bird catcher put a grain of oats down on the ground and a plate over it and a stick on the plate. This stick was tied to a "sgiathag" which was  by the side of the plate and fixed in such a way that if a bird jumped on the stick it would balance and the "sgiathag" would fall and the bird is a prisoner until his pursuer comes.Another game which was very common in days gone by was paper boat making. Children were taught this toy in school as a lesson. A strip of paper was got and formed into the shape of a boat. Then it was put into a flowing stream and it sails with the current until it sinks.

4811670/4810963/5167517.title: Homemade Toys
4811670/4810963/5167517.text: The boys and girls in this district make some toys for their amusement. The boys make snares for snaring rabbits out of thin copper wire with a loop at one end.They also make slings for throwing stones. This is made from a bit of light leather, and two cords attached to it. The leather is about six inches long, and the cord is tied on to each end of it.    Pop-guns were made by the old people, but we do not see them in use at all at the present day. This toy was made from a piece of an elder tree It was about one foot long with a hole cleaned out at the centre. Then there was a cork of wet paper packed firmly in to each end of it, and one of the corks was forced to the centre by means of a stick called the "ram rod", and the air pressure between the two corks forced one to go out very quickly.     The girls make daisy-chains in the following way:- They make a hole in the centre of the daisy, and then they put the stem of another one in the hole. In this way they tie a long string of daisies together.

4921742/4902393/5168470.title: Homemade Toys
4921742/4902393/5168470.text: A crib for catching birds is made with twigs and elder on a timber frame about one foot square. The four twigs are looped in the four corners and tied with a cord. Straight elders are put in through the loops and tied at intervals with cord to the top. A light twig is made into a bow and put into the two back corners. The crib is raised up at one side with  a "Gallóg" and a piece of twig called a "baitín breagach" or the liardy little stick very light sticks are placed across the bow and a bait of corn laid on the ground at the back.   A swing is made with two ropes haging on two trees the ropes are tied to the ends of the board and a person sits on the board and another person swings him back and forth.

4921742/4902394/5168471.title: Homemade Toys
4921742/4902394/5168471.text:
A swing is a home made toy, it is made by putting a rope on to one branch and the other rope tied to another branch then get a bag and put it on the rope, then the swing is made. When we want a football. When a pig would be killed, to get the bladder and fill it with air. There is also another way of making a football. We get a pocket of an old garment then stuff it with hay and sew it up. I often made a hurley also. I would make it out of a furze stick which is also called a "furze root". I used to shape it out in the shape of a hurley with a hatchet and I would finish it off with a knife. I made a ball of corks and thread, This ball is called a slitter. First of all I got four corks and I wound thread around the four corks, until I had it a large size. Then I
(continues on next page)

4921913/4900173/5168482.title: Homemade Toys
4921913/4900173/5168482.text: The most popular toy made by the girls around this district is a "necklace" made out of a string of diasies. The boys make catapults and pop=guns, and whistles out of elder trees. The boys also make snares out of a stick called "cipín" and a foot and a halfofsnare wire and some cord for to tie the wire to the cipín and a thick stick called a peg about a foot long. They use these snares for catching rabbits. The boys also make "cribs" for catching birds, it is made of four pieces of flat board nailed together in the form of a frame and lettuce wire is stretched across it. The crib is set up by putting a thin piece of briar under one end of it and raising the crib about four inches from the ground and bird seed is scattered underneath it and as the bird goes in he is sure to tip the crib and as the least little tip would knock it he is trapped.

4921743/4902526/5170445.title: Herbs
4921743/4902526/5170445.text:
Long ago people, especially the young people made toys some are even made yet, they made air guns out of a stick of elder, they made slings and catapults with which to throw stones, and they made snares for catching rabbits, they also made Teetotums out of a piece of wood. This is how they made an air gun, they got a piece of a stick of elder about a
(continues on next page)

4921711/4892912/5170685.title: Weather-Lore
4921711/4892912/5170685.text:
(continued from previous page)
of rain, and a rainbow in the evening is a sign of fine weather. Tá ceo ar Muisire agus clarac lom an comhaire soinnine is fearr ar domhan.



In the winter time when frost and snow are on the ground it is a great pastime to make cribs to catch blackbirds and thrushes in the crib. The crib is usually made from sally twigs it is only a frame work kept together by twines securely tied. First there is a square of twigs made and in each corner they are nailed by means of a short nail or bot tack. Each square is graduated until it becomes narrow or dome-shaped on top. When you have them securely tied your crib is made. You get a small stick called a  gabhalóg and from this is another little stick connected with the upright or gabhalóg, on this stick or near it the bait is fixed and as the bird jumps on the twig she stirs the gabhalóg and she is enclosed within.

4921711/4892913/5170691.title: Homemade Toys
4921711/4892913/5170691.text: A dancing man is made by getting a sheet of cardboard cut to the shape of a man's body then his legs and hands are tied to his body with strings, this is also passed through the body and when it is pulled the figure dances.A pop gun is made of elder stick its pith being removed and another stick stuck in the hole and damp paper for bullets.A bow and arrow is made from a tough stick and a string which is tied at each end. The arrow is made from another stick. Then the string is pulled and the arrow is placed in the centre of it and when the string is pulled the arrow goes forward.

4921754/4903641/5170758.title: Homemade Toys
4921754/4903641/5170758.text: Long ago boy's used to make tops out of a thick limb of a tree. They used to cut the makings of three or four tops out of the limb, they used to point the top at the bottom and put a worn stud in it. They used to make snares out of brass wire, they used to put six pieces of wire together and twist them, the snares used to be set where the rabbit came out of the burrow. They used to make a football out of a pig's bladder. First they used to fill it then they would let it get dry before they would play it.

4921772/4905584/5170891.title: How to Make a Snare
4921772/4905584/5170891.text: I could make a snare of wire. The wire is sold in balls for 3d 6d and 1s. The snare can be easily made by putting a nail through the eye in the wire and tying it to the cover of a pot and twisting the cover. When it is twisted enough take it off and put the end of the wire through the end with the eye in it. Then tie a strong cord to it and and tie a peg to the cord. The snare is now ready.

4921772/4905585/5170892.title: Homemade Toys
4921772/4905585/5170892.text:
Get a turnip and scoop out the middle of it having first peeled the skin off. Keep scooping out the middle until you have a shell about a quarter of an inch thick. Then cut two round holes for eyes and a long hole for a nose and another hole the shape of a mouth. When you are making the mouth make four or five teeth also.To make a toy cannon, get a piece of cross-bar of an old mans bicycle about eight inches long for a muzzle. Tie a piece of rubber about six inches long to one end of the piece of bar and tie a middling thick piece of stick on to the rubber also. Before you tie the rubber to the stick put one end of it into the muzzle then you have the
(continues on next page)

4921772/4905587/5170893.title: Homemade Toys
4921772/4905587/5170893.text: To make a gun get an elder stick and scoop the pith out. Then get a piece of rubber and tie it to one end of the stick. Get another thin stick and tie it to the the other end of of the rubber. Insert the stick into hallow. Put a stone into the hallow pull the rubber and it will shoot the stone far away.

4921744/4902637/5170959.title: Homemade Toys
4921744/4902637/5170959.text:
Long ago bought toys were very scarce in this district Kanturk. If the days were wet the children had to remain in-doors. While they were in-doors they made toys of wood, namely, boats, guns, tops and all sorts of toys.The boys made dolls' houses and furniture for the little girls. The girls made the dolls for the houses. They stuffed the dolls with straw and very often the mothers knitted covers and frocks for the dolls. The boys also made various animals from wood. If they did them well they would often give them as a present or ornament.Mothers made stuffed dolls and rabbits and sent them to poor children' bazaars. In Ireland nowadays the majority og children have a great many toys to play with, but long ago it was different and any toy the children had was made by themselves.The girls made dolls from straw and then spent some time in dressing them. They also made chains from flowers and hats from rushes. These hats are made by weaving the rushes around a thick rush and afterwards tyring on top. It is next trimmed with flowers.Boys made guns from elder branches and it is worked somewhat in the same way as a bicycle-pump and is used for the purpose of shooting haw-stones. 4921780/4906597/5178098.title: Homemade Toys - Bird Traps
4921780/4906597/5178098.text:
It was a common practice with boys about fifty years ago to make bird traps called "cribs" with which to catch birds in the winter time.  The frame of the crib was made of four sticks each about fourteen inches long forming a square, to the corners of which four twigs were tied so as to form loops for the sticks which formed the sides of the crib.  These loops were also about fourteen inches in the length and met over the centre of the frame where they were tied together.The sides of the crib were made of light sticks which were put in pairs that is first the front and back ones and then the two sides sticks, and so on until the "crib" when finished looked like a small pyramid.A pliable twig was used as a bough the ends of which were inserted in one in one side of the crib just above the frame.  The crib when set, rested on that side of the frame.  The opposite side was lifted up about ten inches from the ground.  A forked stick about ten inches in length was stuck in the ground in front of the crib.
(continues on next page)

4921780/4906605/5178185.title: Homemade Toys - Water Guns
4921780/4906605/5178185.text: From a plant which in this district was called the "boom bulawn" the boys long ago used to make what they called "water-guns".  They were on the same principle and were very like the bicycle pump of the present day.  The rod was a stick with a rag tied at one end which fitted tightly into the "gun barrel".  These "guns" were like flowerful syringes and sometimes the boys would divide into two armies and engage in a "war" in which the ammunition was the water of the stream on the banks of which they got the material from which they made the guns, but the "war" never lasted very long because the barrels of the guns were very easily split.

4921784/4906871/5178557.title: Homemade Toys
4921784/4906871/5178557.text: In this district boys make whistles out of empty thread reels. They cut off one of the verges and tie light rubber over the hole at the end. Then they blow in through the other end and it makes a kind of music.    They make hurleys out of sticks which grow beside a stream. Those sticks are turned at the bottom of the first shoot and excellant hurleys can be made from them if they are well "dressed".   They make snares for catching rabbits. First they buy snare-wire, which can be obtained at any hard-ware shop. Then they get six wires each about one foot and a half long. They put a nail in each end so as to twist them. They separate the wires on one end and put the other end through through the hole. Next they twist cords and tie them to this end. On the end of the cord they make a loop. In this they put a stick which is known as the "peg" and is used for keeping the snare staked to the ground, so that the rabbit could not carry it away.

4921784/4906872/5178563.title: Homemade Toys
4921784/4906872/5178563.text: Boys make lamps out of ink bottles.  They fill the bottle with paraffain oil.  They put a cord through the cork and when lit it shows fairly good light.   They made guns out strong weeds which grow in wet places. Those weeds are empty inside. They then get a stick and tie a cloth around the end of it.  This they put into the weed and it throws water like a bicycle pump.   They made hurley-balls out of small bags packed with horse-hair. Those balls were not lively and so they serve the purpose very well.    They make music instruments out of a rack and paper. They put the paper around the rack and then they blow through it.

4921784/4906873/5178568.title: Homemade Toys
4921784/4906873/5178568.text: Girls make necklaces out of candle grease. They melt the grease and make it up in small balls. Then they hole them with a needle. They put thread through the holes and paint the beads with silver paint. When finished they look very pretty.They make dolls out of cardboard. They get very strong cardboard and cut out the eyes, nose, mouth, etc on it. Then they used to dress it.They also made belts by weaving sweet wrappers together.

Boys make guns with elder sticks. They take out the soft stuff of the elder sticks and they put in a piece of stone or cork into the hole and they then drive it out with a nail or strong wire. They also make tops with reels, after the thread is taken off. They pare one end of the reels and made it in a point. They put a piece of a stick into the hole and then they would spin it and whip it. A catapult, a sling, and a bow and Arrow are very dangerous toys. A Catapult is made from a gabhlóg and a piece of rubber. 4921733/4901424/5180577.title: Homemade Toys - Saint Bridget's Crosses
4921733/4901424/5180577.text:
In years gone by, it was the custom for school girls to wear on their right shoulder a cross in honour of Saint Bridget on the first of February. These crosses were made by the girls themselves. For weeks beforehand they would be collecting pieces of coloured silk and this would be out in little pieces about one inch and a half long and a half inch wide and put ones across on a piece of cardboard, cut in the shape of a cross. They were sewn on firmly. These crosses were very nice and it is a pity the custom has died out. There used be great competition between the girls, as to which would have the nicest cross.



There were no dolls long ago, like there are now, so little girls had to make their own. Very nice ones were made of pieces of old, worn cloth for the stuffing, to make the body. Nice little pieces of bright, coloured material for the clothes.

My father snares for trout. He gets four long hairs off a horses tail, twists them together leaving a small loop at the end. When the four hairs are twisted into one, the end is put through the little loop and drawn through until a loop large enough for a trout's head to go through, is left. The end of the snare is then tied to the top of the fishing rod. On a bright summers day, you can see the trout, lying in the bottom of the hole. He puts the fishing rod down slowly though the water, until he gets the snare in front of the trouts head. He pulls it back slowly round the head, then gives one quick pull to the rod. The snare tightens round the head, and holds the trout until it is pulled out quickly on the bank.

4921736/4901754/5182391.title: Toy-Making
4921736/4901754/5182391.text: Long ago, children made their own tops. The tops were made by cutting off the top of a handle of a spade.  This piece of timber was pointed at one end, with a knife or chisel.  Then grooves were cut in the top inorder that cords would be put into them to spin.  Then a spear was driven in the top.  Then cords were woven from the top of the spear until all the grooves were covered. Then a cord was tired to the top and the cord was caught in the small finger, the top was thrown, the cord was kept in the hand, and then the top went spinning.

4921736/4901755/5182392.title: Toy-Making
4921736/4901755/5182392.text: In olden times girls in their spare time when coming and going from school made necklaces and bracelets, they made those toys from daisies.  They first tied what we call "soldiers" together, they then broke the stems from the daisies and put the soldiers through them, they kept doing so until the chain was the required size They used those chains for decorating statues and altars at home, and offered them to the Blessed Virgin because it is the earliest flower of the year.

4921736/4901756/5182393.title: Toy-Making
4921736/4901756/5182393.text: Page 524Flop- guns were made from elder. This was done by cutting a piece of elder about 9 ins long and about 2 ins wide.  Then the pit was scooped out with a piece of wire, the wire was heated and put into the hole to make, it fine. Then, get a piece of brown paper, wet it, and press it into the hole with a piece of an oak stick called the ramming stick.  Get another piece of paper, wet it, this is called the wad, blow into the gun and press the wad into the open end of the gun with the ramming stick.  There is air in the gun and the pressure of the air drives the wad out with great force.  If the wad hit a bird it would kill it.

Sometimes the little girls made straw dolls. In winter the boys make bird traps. When the frost is on the ground the boys catch birds with the traps. The rabbits are snared. The children made toy soldiers and toy dolls. The old people can tell the use they made of these toys. The children had a strong peg stuck in the ground to keep the rabbit from pulling the snare with him.The boy that is setting the snare sets it between two hops. Playthings that children make for themselves are a great deal better than those which are bought for them, and really please more. Country children make any amount of toys.    The little boys long ago used to make an amount of pop-guns. A pop-gun is made of elder with the inside removed, then a ramrod is made. Then get a piece of wet paper and plug it into, one end, then plug the other. Then press the ramrod, and the pressure of air forces out the paper. The children long ago were also very fond of making slings for killing birds. A sling is made from and ash stick, or any rod that has a spring in it. 4921846/4896291/5184397.title: Folklore - Homemade Toys
4921846/4896291/5184397.text: Long ago in Ireland when there were not much toys made the people used to make some themselves.   For instance the catapult which was made at home was used for throwing stones. It was made with a "gabalog" and a piece of rubber tied on to each end of it and also a tongue of a boot tied on to the rubber.   For trapping mice it was the usual custom amount the people to get the top of a chalk pipe and fill it with crumbs. then a basin was put on it. Then when the mouse would come and try to get bread the basin would fall on him.    Frames of pictures were also made with tory tops sealed together with wax.   Necklaces were also made with daises. A number of daises were got and were put through a plant which is called the soldier.

4921686/4889890/5184551.title: Handmade Toys
4921686/4889890/5184551.text:
In olden times the old men of the district made toys to amuse small children.   They made whistles from eleder and bamboo rods by cutting out the centre and then by making a small hole at one end.   Writing pens were also made from the goose quill and they were considered better than the steel-pens now in use.-----------------------------------------------------   The young girls of long ago made rag dolls, by filling a little bag with saw dust, tying a cord around the centre to form a waist putting two burnt matches for legs and a small chestnut stuck on for a head
(continues on next page)

4921809/4894571/5184584.title: Homemade Toys
4921809/4894571/5184584.text: Boys make snares for catching rabbits. they buy some snare wire and make the snares. They put six wires in them and twist themThey tie them to pegs with bits of cords and put them up in rabbits' paths in furze brakes. They go to see them very early in the morning before stray dogs would eat them. They sell them for sixpence each. Rabbits were very dear this year and it encouraged many boys to go snaring them.

4921809/4894576/5184592.title: Homemade Toys
4921809/4894576/5184592.text: Long ago the people used to make alot of toys.  They used to cut things in turnips and in timber  They cut out trees and birds in timber.The birds would be put up on the trees and the children would try to shoot them, off the trees with a gun.  They cut out horses and cars in timber.  When the horse would be cut out he would  be painted.

4921840/4895779/5184776.title: Homemade Toys
4921840/4895779/5184776.text:
Home made toys were used more than bought ones by the children of this district (Grange, Fermoy Co Cork) long ago.They used to make necklaces with a string of daisies or beads. The used thread a needle and then put the needle in through the daisies or beads. Another way for making them was to put a hole in the stem of one daisy and put the stem of the next one in through it. When it was long enough to fit round the neck the stems of the two end daisies were knotted together to serve as a fastening.



In former times children of this district (Cornhill, Fermoy, Co. Cork) used make dolls in the following way. Two flat pieces of sticks were got and fixed together in the form of a cross. Then they used sew a piece of cloth rather loosely around the cross.
(continues on next page)

4921840/4895781/5184779.title: Homemade Toys
4921840/4895781/5184779.text: In former times girls of this district (Grange, Fermoy parish, Co Cork) and to make their own toys. This is the way they used to make dolls. They used fill a paper bag with hay or straw. This was the doll's body. Then a small turnip was got for the head and holes cut in it for the eyes and mouth. The nose was also shaped on it. Two small pieces of glass were put into the holes for the eyes. Then a short sharp piece of ash was stuck through the head and down into the body.Girls used to make dolls' cots also. They used first mak a rectangular frame by tying four pieces of wood together in the required shape. Font upright sticks were attached at the corners to serve as legs. Cords or threads were then tied across and up and down the frame and on these the doll was laid.

4921840/4895782/5184781.title: Homemade Toys
4921840/4895782/5184781.text:
In former times toys were not so numerous as they are at the present time. There were no toy factories nor toy shops so children used to make their own toys at home.The boys used to make a flogging top out of a spool by pointing one end of it. They used to drive a nail through the centre for a sport. These tops would not last long as the wood in the spool was easily broken.Another toy which was made at home was the flute. It was made out of an elder or bamboo stick. The pith was taken out and the lower end was made hollow while the hole at the top was stopped. Six small holes were made for the finges on the side, and one larger hole near the top through which the player used to blow.

4921875/4897862/5184942.text:
I got this information from my father James Wilson of Walterstown and it is as follows:-Necklaces - long ago the children used to amuse themselves by making necklaces. 5177598/5172057/5185256.title: Toys and Pastimes
5177598/5172057/5185256.text:
Toys and pastimes                      10th..January '38Boys and girls are naturally inclined to have many pastimes during their tender years.I have made a dolls house of wood wih two windows and a door in it. I fitted it up with all the household necessetys and then gave a tea party to my companions and we had a very enjoyable evening.I also had a great big doll for which I made many dresses. I was presented with a little wardrobe from Santa Claus in which i put the dresses. I also made a pair of stockings and a pinafore for the doll.Later on as I advanced in years I played hurling and on one occasion we had a challenge match between Clonlara and Doona which was played in the latter place with Cllr Meany as refree. But Conlara gained the day, it was a very exciting game.Another game I played was Crokey of which we had many challenge matches and spent many a pleasent hour at some.Another favortie pastime we have had during the Summer months when my companions were home on holidays is swimming
(continues on next page)

4921850/4910334/5185289.title: Toys
4921850/4910334/5185289.text: My father used always make a pegging-top for himself. He used get a bit of holly about two and a half inches long and about two inches wide. The holly should be well seasoned. Then he'd pare it down to a point at one end and the other end would be left round by paring away the corners. When he had it well shaped and made smooth he'd bring it to the blacksmith. When the smith would not be busy he would make a steel spear and drive it into the point of the top. This would be the best kind of a top for pegging because the steel spear would be sharp for taking "mutties" out of other tops, and when the holly would be well seasoned it would be hard for other tops to knock 'mutties' off it. Sometimes they used peg a drift from Casey's corner down as far as Stable's Cross and there would be a whole lot of them pegging away.Twas easy to make a slashing-top for a girl with any piece of timber and a nail.

4921850/4910335/5185291.title: Toys
4921850/4910335/5185291.text:
A small basket to hang on a girl's necklace is made out of a chestnut. Get a fairly round chestnut. Make two cuts with a very sharp knife close together over the top of the chestnut. Then make two more cuts around the sides of the chestnut till they would meet the ends of the first two cuts. Cut away the part between the cuts and scrape out the inside and the basket is made. If it isn't scraped out carefully it is very easy to break it.  [drawing on page here]A whistle is made out of a chestnut by making a hole in the top and cleaning out the inside of it.A whistle is made by taking a piece of a flagger and holding it just between the thumbs with the hands closed. Blow into the hole between the two thumbs. A Sling is made by getting a small piece of soft leather or the tongue of a boot. It must be cut square and a small hole

4921850/4910337/5185292.title: Toys
4921850/4910337/5185292.text:
A cat-and-dog is made from two pieces of stick. The cat is a small piece about three inches long, The two ends of it must be pointed.The dog is a long piece Put the cat lying on the ground and hit it with the dog. You should hit it near the end so that it will jump up in the air. When it jumps up you should keep on hitting it up in the air as long as you can. Sometimes two people play it by seeing who can drive the cat the farthest with one blow.



Girls make a necklace out of daisies and buttercups.A hurley is made out of a piece of ash growing out of the side of a ditch or out of the side of a cliff.A candlestick is is made out of half of a turnip. Cut a hole in the middle to fit the end of the candle.Belts are made out of sweet papers.

4921850/4910338/5185295.title: Toys
4921850/4910338/5185295.text: A whistle is made out of a piece of bamboo stick. A hole is cut in the stick and the pith is taken out and a small piece of stick is put in at the bottom and another piece in the top.Baskets are made from rushes that grow on the bank of the river. Crosses are made from bullrushes.Riding whips are made by plaiting bull-rushes and then binding them with more bullrushesA ghost is made out of a turnip. Pare the turnip like a man's face, put bits of matches for teeth. Sweets are made out of sugar and butter. Put them in a saucepan over the fire and mix them. When they are cool again it is just the same as toffee.

4921767/4905194/5187091.title: Homemade Toys
4921767/4905194/5187091.text:
Girls made chains from daisies pink and white ones by drawing a needle with a very long thread through the centre of the daisy and wore them as we wear necklaces or girdles now.Girls stuffed white cloth with rags to form a doll putting a white border cap on its head and painting the lips with blackberries. Boys made a line by stringing thread spools and fastening it across the kitchen for keeping stockings and light clothes over it. Boys made flog guns by scooping out the soft pulp of an elder branch taking a thin bit of [?] and fastening a tow on one end then filling the elder with water putting a soft cork on the other end with the wooden stick shooting through by forcing the water to squirt around. Scooping the inside of a turnip and shaping out a space for the eyes and paring around the mouth to shape the teeth and then placing it in a dark room with a bit of lighted candle was often done to scare people.

4921728/4894086/5187627.title: Homemade Toys
4921728/4894086/5187627.text:
Children themselves are often quite inventive in the manufacture and procuring of toys. It is quite a common thing to see a boy especially, tie a piece of cord around another's waist and play "horse". Even if a companion cannot be got a child will tie a piece of string to the back of a chair which he will use as reins and thus satisfy his desires in the matter of driving. Or better still he will go riding on the kitchen sweeping brush.The toy car is made by just attaching the cord to any kind of suitable box (cardboard, timber etc) and having all sorts of collections within go racing around the floor with it. Later as the inventive spirit develops the boys puts wheels under his box. These are made with tins of polish-boxes or thread-spools (or reels as they are always called locally.)A toy-gun is made from a piece of the Alder-tree, the middle of which is holed by a piece of heated wire. A piece of rubber band is attached to one end. Sticks (small pieces e.g. matches) can be fired through with it. Some boys use a thread-spool instead of the Alder.A whistler is made from a piece of Alder also. The soft middle is removed and an opening is
(continues on next page)

4921728/4894088/5187635.title: Homemade Toys
4921728/4894088/5187635.text:
Boys also make cages for trapping birds when there is a cover of snow on the ground in Winter. Four light flat boards about 2" wide and 15" long are made into a square by fastening with a light nail. A light framework is then erected on this and twigs (sallies) are woven from the bottom upwards until a cage finishes at a point on top. A minature gabhlóg is got from a little piece of stick or twig and this keeps one side of the trap raised up for the bird to go in. A twig is set inside in a bow shape and a piece of cord attached from this to the gabhlóg causes the latter to pull when the bird stands on the bow-twig, with the result that the cage drops and the bird is enclosed.



A Sling for throwing stones is made from a piece of leather about four inches long and one and a half inches wide having a hole near each end in which two pieces of cord are tied. One piece of cord is supposed to be longer than the other. The long piece of cord is wound around the hand while the other piece is held with the fingers. This piece is let go when one throws. The leather is usually a tongue of a shoe or boot.

4921728/4894089/5187639.title: Homemade Toys
4921728/4894089/5187639.text:
A catapult for throwing stones is made with a forked piece of stick known locally as a gabhlog having a piece of rubber attatched with a [ca?] The stone.A mouth-organ can be made by placing some tissue paper over the teeth of a comb.A swing is made by both boys and girls by fastening a strong rope to the branch of a tree. Sometimes the rope is doubled and a flat piece of board with four holes for the rope to go through is provided as a seat though rarely this is to be seen.See-Saw. Boys & girls play this game in many ways. A fairly long plank supported on the trunk of a tree or on a low wall serves admirably. It is a game that is not played frequently in the locality probably on account of the material necessary.Soldiers is another game played by boys at seasonal times. They play with "reels", tory-tops from the fir-tree and even horse-buttons. One boy holds

4921768/4905235/5187918.title: Homemade Toys
4921768/4905235/5187918.text: 1.Long ago girls made toys by getting a needle and thread and draw them through daisies until the chain was long enough.2. Boys make catterpults by getting a branch off the blackthorn tree tabhlóg shaped, and tied rubber to each side of it. They then put a stone in the middle of the rubber and in that way they could kill birds.3. They get a scithóg and put a little stick under one side of it and tied a cord to the stick and put a grain of meal under the scithóg and when the bird would go in pull the cord and the bird was caught.4.Snares were made by twisting six thin wires together and tying an eyelet of a shoe to one side of it. They put the other side out through the eyelet and tie a stick to it.5. Girls made hats of rushes by weaving them like a basket and decorating them with a string of daisies.6.Boys got large thread and put a piece of steel through the hole in the centre, and with a length of whip-cord made an excellent spinning top.

5177636/5174889/5188145.title: Béaloideas - Toys and Pastimes
5177636/5174889/5188145.text:
14           Béaloideas  19-1-'38               Toys and Pastimes.                  There are many "Toys and pastimes" which girls and boys have nowadays .In the Summer time a great pastime for girls is making daisy chains.The first thing they do is  to gather a bunch of daisies .One of the daisies is then taken and a hole put in the stem of it ,the stem of another daisy is then taken and put through,and so on until a long chain is made.it is then fastened and worn around the neck.Another pastime for girls is needlework .Some girls can make dolls.The dolls are usually made with pieces of cloth.Long ago the girls used to make harps for St Patrick's Day.Another pastime is knitting .Every girl can because it is taught in school.                        Some pastimes which boy have are as follows .Hurling and spinning Tops.Another pastime for boys is making snares.Those snares are very useful for snaring rabbits,making cradle is another famous pastime.                In the Winter time the ponds are when the ponds are frozen  over a great pastime is skating on the ice.Another pastime for boys and girls is reading .Some boys and girls get books from the library and they read them during the long Winter's nights.Pupils name : Kitty Hanrahan.
(continues on next page)

4921870/4897359/5190360.title: Homemade Toys
4921870/4897359/5190360.text:
CatapultsBoys used Catapults to fire stones at birds. They were made of a gabhlóg and two pieces of elastic. The elastic was tied to the gabhlóg with two pieces of twines. A tongue of a boot was tied to each piece of elastic. A stone was put into the tongue. When the gabhlóg is pulled the elastic stretched and when you let the tongue go the stone flies off.               Tops.Tops were made long ago from a reel and a nail. The reel is pared at one end and the head of a nail is put in at that side. The boys made lashers of a piece of stick and twine. Then the boys would spin the tops and hit them with the lashers and they used have races.               Pea Shooters.Pea Shooters are made from an elder stick. 4921731/4894385/5191305.title: Homemade Toys
4921731/4894385/5191305.text:
Home - made Toys.Girls and boys always amused them- selves and still amuse themselves by making certain toys.Girls made flower chains and flower girdles in Summer time. First they pick big bunches of daisies. Then they get a needle and a strong double cotton thread and put a knot on one end. They put in the needle through the centre of the daisy and draw the thread through it to the end, and then through another one and so on to the end, and then through another and so on till the thread is full up with daisies. In the same way children made necklaces and bracelets out of large and small beads.They also make daisy chains by putting a split in the stem of one daisy and put the stem of another daisy through the opening and so on till a long chain is made.Children nowadays make belts of the glossy papers which wrap up packs of cigarettesHats were also mad from rushes.Little girls used make their own dolls out of timber. They used get a piece of timber and cut it out the shape of a head,

4921803/4908620/5191470.title: Homemade Toys
4921803/4908620/5191470.text:
Catapults, cribs (for catching birds) swings, see saws and blow pipes were made in Milford. Catapults are used in throwing stones at birds or certain objects. Cribs are used for catching birds and they are made of sticks in the form of a box.To make a 'swing' two rope are tied to a tree and a board is tied to the ends. Small stones are used for a blow pipe. By blowing in to one end they come out quickly at the other.



Extra: Daisy chains, top and pop guns were made in the homes here. The tops were made of spools into which pieces of iron which were sharp at one end were fitted.



Extra: Stones were put into a box to make a rattler for a child. Whistles were made out of horse-chestnuts & pop-guns were made out of alder sticks. Boats were made out of the twigs which grew on the edges of ponds.



Extra:    Small carts, wheel-barrows, small brackets & timber plates were made locally. Timber egg-cups, spoons & toy shovels were made also. (Since the fret-work machines were bought Messrs Daniel Hennigan & P.M. Murphy have made several useful articles). T.T.O'S.

5177655/5177483/5191952.title: Homemade Toys
5177655/5177483/5191952.text:
Get four pieces of sally rod and tie the ends together so as to make a square then get two pieces of twine and tie them across from corner to corner. You then place more rods across each other making sure to have them getting shorter after every layer until you come to the top and you will have it closed in and the pieces of twine will keep it position. You then get a very light sally and fix it on the back inside so as it will come out about middleways in the basket you call that a bough. Next you get a fork stick which is called a Goulogue and put it standing up against the basket but you must have the basket standing on one end. Then you get a light twig which is called a trigger and put one end of it through the fork of the Goulogue so as the basket will rest on it then bring the other part back and let it barely touch the bough which you have raised
(continues on next page)

5177655/5177485/5191953.title: Homemade Toys
5177655/5177485/5191953.text: Children made guns from elder sticks, by taking out the middle and pressing in a bit of paper half wat then put in another bit of paper. Then press with a stick made for the use and from the pressure it would act like a bullet.. They used also make slings for shooting birds with two rubbers a stick and a piece of leather. Others would make bird baskets for catching birds alive this was made with sally sticks tied together with twine and a twig tied underneath to make a bough, and the basket held up with a bit of stick and when the bird perches on the bough the weight of him knocks the cage and then he is caught.

5177655/5177486/5191954.title: Old Toys
5177655/5177486/5191954.text: Children made bird baskets to catch birds and made cages for to keep them out of sallies.They made balls for hurling out of old cotton wool.  They made foot balls from the skin of two rabbits sewed together and packed with old rags they also put corks into it so that it could hop.

5177655/5177487/5191955.title: Homemade Toys
5177655/5177487/5191955.text: Children made teddy bears by means of a piece of canvas and a small bunch of hay and two block buttons  They stuffed the hay into the canvas and sewed block buttons for eyes.

You then get a very light sally and fix it on the back inside so as it will come out about midways in the basket, you call that a bough. Next you

5170142/5169248/5192633.title: Homemade Toys
5170142/5169248/5192633.text: Many children make toys for themselves. They make tops, marbles, slings, toy dolls, and others. A top is made from a spool and a piece of stick. The spool is cut to a point. The stick is pointed also like the point of a pencil. The stick must be firm in the hole.Toy marbles are made from a special kind of clay. It is of a blue cloour. Blue clay is taken and mixed with a little water. Then it is shaped into round balls. it is left for a day or so and they are as hard as any bought marbles now a days.Another home-made toy is a sling. It is made from a piece of leather and two pieces of string. A hole is made in each end of the leather and one string in each.When the person is throwing the stone from the sling it must be flung with grear force.

5170147/5169682/5195691.title: Toys
5170147/5169682/5195691.text:
In my spare time I amuse myself with making toys of every description.The toys I prefer making are dolls' houses, wheel barrows and mud pies.I get for the cake dry clay for the flour, wet mud for milk, stones and haws for currents, the juice of haws for lemon peel sand for salt, lime for soade, and a lid of a cocoa tn for an oven on which to bake the cake. I then leave it out in the sun till it is well baked, although it is only a "mud cake". From wood I make wheel-barrows, dolls' houses and carts.I make a weather cock by getting a lid from a jam jar, cutting nicks around the edges of it and putting it on top of a stick about six inches long, and putting it on top of a house. It will then go around with the wind.More often my pastime is ornament making. I like making daisy chains, cockle shell bracelets and other ornaments.I make holes in holly berries, then string them and wear them around my neck, but you may be sure they don't be long in breaking. I also make holly pearls by dipping the berries in candle grease and letting it harden. When strung together they
(continues on next page)

5170147/5169694/5195706.title: Local Marriage Customs
5170147/5169694/5195706.text:
(continued from previous page)
It was costume that when they were leaving to go to the chapel an old boot would be thrown after them. Today they hire a car for the wedding day and for the following Sunday. Straw boys are rarely heard of either When the straw boys would go to the house it was a costume for them to dance the bride and b'have them-selves. Today if they went to a wedding it would be to cause annoyance and not to behave themselves.

Some of the things which cause the grown-ups to wonder, is how children spend most of their time trying to invent useful articles out of nothing. In early childhood little girls seen most of their time gathering of delph and china, which has been broken and they select a quiet little place, there they build a little house and it would surprise you how clean it is kept.On a Sunday a little school chum of the proud house owner may come, on the day previous she makes fancy cakes out of clay.First she gets a broken basin, into this she puts clay, she dampens it
(continues on next page)

5170138/5168949/5195835.title: Homemade Toys
5170138/5168949/5195835.text:
Every boy and many girls find amusement in making all sorts of toys. The firls make dolls. They make them from moss and old clothes or rags. First of all they sew up the cloth so that they can fill it with moss or old rags. Then they get a cloth for her head but it has to be small and they fill it with hay or hard cloth. They get two straight sticks and puts cloth around them for hands. They also get two straight thick sticks and puts cloth around them for legs. Then they mark the eyes and the nose and mouth on the head with ink. Sometimes they get wool for hair or some old hair and tie it on to her head. The boys make many sorts of toys. The make carts out of boards. They saw the wheels round and put a hole in the middle of them. They put a stick from one wheel to the other and they nail them together. They get two long boards and two short boards and nail them
(continues on next page)

5170138/5168952/5195841.title: Homemade Toys
5170138/5168952/5195841.text:
Every boy and many girls find amusement in making toys. Girls like stringing flowers and making necklaces and chains. They also make belts of flowers in the Summer. Boys make balls of paper stuffed with rags. They amuse themselves with these balls. Girls often like to make dolls of moss covered with a white cloth they sew the cloth all round. They sew arms and legs ' into the dolls. Then they make a little dress for it. They get wool and they put it on for hair. Then they mark eyes and a mouth on its face. They like carrying the dolls about everywhere. Boys amuse themselves by getting four lids and a big board and they nail it to the axles. Then they put sides into it. They tie a little rein to the cart. They bring it to a high hill and one of them sits in it. Another catches the pulls ' it down
(continues on next page)

5170139/5168996/5195934.title: Homemade Toys
5170139/5168996/5195934.text: Boys are very fond of making toys from pieces of wood. Some scoop a turnip and form a man's head, by putting two eyes and a mouth in the proper places. The boys used to frighten the ceilidhers when they were returning home at night. They made an artificial man and put a lighted candle in the centre of the head to pretend that it was a ghost.The young boys still make toys from spools and display great ingenuity in carrying out the work. Some millions of pounds worth of toys are imported into this country each year from Japan, China and Germany. Some home - made toys are nicer than foreign toys, but the young folk prefer bought ones.

5162115/5155547/5196070.title: Homemade Toys
5162115/5155547/5196070.text:
Home Made ToysBows and arrows. A bow is made from a sally stick which there is a spring in. It can be made from an ash stick too. A thin piece of cord is got then and tied to each side of the stick which makes a bow of it. Then you get a thin stick about a foot in length this is the arrow you will put on the twine pull the twine and arrow and let it off and it will fire about ten yards.A Flack gun. get a wide elder stick make a whole down through the centre of it get a piece of wet paper and shove it in at one end of it get an other piece a put it in a the other end get a stick and shove it through it and it will make a shotSlingers get two peices of twineferelly long and piece of taoibeen leather make two wholes in it and tie the twine to the leather get a stone and put it on the leather wind one piece of twine around your finger and hold the other in your hand give a few swings and then let go the one that is in your hand and the stone will go very farCribsPeople make birds[?] cribs for catching birds first of all they make a frame of four pieces of lat and nail them together to make a frame then tie two pieces of twine across from each end leave them loose and get elder sticks a cut them shorter as your going up along then [?] a small stick and put it to each corner[?] this callsd the bellyband. they get the gowlog and the bateen[?]
(continues on next page)

5177649/5176667/5202131.title: Toys and Pastimes - Rabbit Snare
5177649/5176667/5202131.text:
made of brass wire. Twist 4 brass wires of about 1 foot together, forming a small loop at each end. Bend & get one end thro' the other loop to form snare. To the other end tie a strong string which is attached to a peg, driven into the ground
(continues on next page)

5177649/5176668/5202132.title: Toys and Pastimes - Rabbit Snare
5177649/5176668/5202132.text:
(continued from previous page)
The snare itself is supported by a split stick driven into ground, at a height of about 5 or 6 inches. The wire outside the loop is inserted in the split. The snare is at middle of hop & rabbit jumps right in.Fish are sometimes snared, sometimes with a wire snare & sometimes with a horse-hair one. The snare is attached to a rod, slipped over fish's head & pulled suddenly.



Tops are sometimes made out of wooded reels (tread). Cut in two, pare to point & drive down wooden spear thro' hole.

5162134/5157131/5215857.title: How to Make Daisy Chains
5162134/5157131/5215857.text: 464   How to Make Daisy Chains.In Summer when girls have no other way to occupy their leisure hours they make daisy chains.          This is a very simple past time and it is made as follows:-   First of all the daisies are picked.These daisies must have long and strong stems so that another stem will go through them.There is a hole made at the end of the stem with a needle . Then the stem of another daisy is put through it                        This is continued on until the daisy chain is long enough to go round the persons neck.           At the end of the chain the stem of the last daisy is fastened to the head of the first daisy.

5215779/5207799/5218464.title: Bréagáin
5215779/5207799/5218464.text:
My mother showed me how to make a cradle for catching birds. She told me to get a knife and go to the wood and cut five or six pieces of sticks, and tie them together with a string. Then to get a couple of strait sticks and cut them at a right length and to join them in with the other sticks and tie them tightly together. Then you have to get a strong  piece of a stick to put under the cradle to hold it up when you are setting it.
(continues on next page)

I got a spool from my Mother and I paired one end of it untilh it comes to a point then I put a little peg in the hole.A Cradle.You can make a cradle by getting fore rods each about 18 inches long. Then you must split two of them on both ends and pair the ends of the other two and fix them into the splits. Then you have to get for ihin rods

My father told me how they sued to make a hatcogy long ago they used to go to the bog on a Sunday for rushes then would soart out the rushes and get them all the one size then they would mgke a plait of rushes then they would stick more rushes in the plat then they would start another plat near the top of the rushes they  would keep plaiting till they would close it in on the top. They way the old people used to make a sun hat

They used to sow a piece of cloth and stuff it with wool.
(continues on next page)

My grandmother told me. about how they used to make a doll long ago. First of all they would get a piece of material & cut out a piece shaped like a round ring. Then they would cut out a piece shaped like two feet & stuf them with wool. After that they would sew them on to the body. They would put two pieces of sticks for the hands. Then they would dress it up in every coloured
(continues on next page)

5215813/5214735/5221498.text:
The girls long ago, amused themselevs by making daisy chains, and by playing Jackstones. This is the way they used make the daisy chains. First they used get a daisy, and they used put a hole in the stem of the daisy.  Then they used get another daisy and they used draw it through the hole in the stem of the first daisy and so on. When playing Jackstones

Then you have to stick a little stick up at each corner and tie them at the top. Then you have to weave rods in and out through these sticks. It is then finished
(continues on next page)

Tom Hughes told me the way to make a snare. First of all you have to get about four yards of snarewire. Then you have to wav four wires together and make the size of a rabits head. and then you you have the set it on a run. where the rabit is runing and when the rabit is runing along he wont see it and he will stick his head in it. Then he will pull the snare
(continues on next page)

Some children make little toys, such as a doll. First of all you get a piece of cloth and stuff it with wool and sew it up together. You get a long piece of cloth and put wool in it and sew it with the other piece and then you get a turnip and put two holes in it for eyes and paint the face with chalk.A rush hatYou get a bunch of rushes and make plaits of the rushes and bring it out to a curve at the top and when you have it completed put a binding
